div1.p:
In the brief biographies contained in the following
pages, we have endeavoured to set before our
readers, as fully as the necessary limits of space
would allow, four noble and striking examples of the
ministry of women.

The subjects of these memoirs are all women who
have lived in our own day, and amid similar social
environments to those which surround ourselves;
none of them were of remarkably high birth, or
possessed of the influence which rank in itself confers
on the inheritor; not one of them was endowed with
genius in the common acceptation of the term,
neither poetry, art, literature, nor the drama, having
bestowed its coveted laurels upon any of them; and
yet the names of Frances Willard, Agnes Weston,
Sister Dora and Catherine Booth will live embalmed
in thousands of grateful memories and hearts, when
others, famous for more brilliant talent, may haply
be forgotten.

But if our four heroines, as they may be called,
using the word in its truest sense, were not distinguished
by dazzling intellectual attainments, they
surely belong to that great, Divinely-endowed band
of whom St. Paul writes in I Cor. xii. 4–10:—"To
one is given, by the Spirit, the word of wisdom; to
another, the word of knowledge, by the same Spirit;
to another, faith, by the same Spirit; to another, the
gifts of healing." Each cultivated, for the glory of
God and the good of her fellow-creatures, the best
powers she possessed, and there are none, however
humble, who may not do the same.

Although we have in Mrs. Booth an instance of
how a busy wife and mother may do a great work
in the world without neglecting the nearer claims of
husband and home, her companions in this volume
furnish notable illustrations of the potential joys and
usefulness of spinsterhood.

Thank God, the day is gone by, we believe never
to return, when the unmarried woman frittered her
years away in pensive dreams of what "might have
been," fancying that all that makes life worth living
has been denied her, sadly thinking that because she
has not been enthroned queen of any man's home,
no opportunities of blessing and being blessed can
await her, or that, having no little ones of her own
about her knee, the mother-heart which sleeps in the
bosom of every good woman must for ever be unsatisfied.
But if there should linger in the mind of
any girl reader of these pages the shadow of a notion
that an unmarried woman can never be quite so
happy or useful as a wife, we think she will hardly
be able to reach the last one without experiencing
a change of opinion. The sight of Frances Willard,
swaying multitudes towards the choice of liberty and
right as with a regal sceptre; of Sister Dora, radiant
as an angel of light in the haunts of suffering and
vice; or of Miss Weston, mothering her jolly Jack
Tars with a heart full of tenderness, and loved as by
a thousand noble sons, is enough to dispel any sentimental
allusion about the emptiness of a single life.

Besides affording instances of the consecration of
ordinary gifts and the wonderful possibilities of
Christian enthusiasm, these four ladies, each and all,
stand out in bold relief as the possessors of strong,
but sanctified wills. There was no namby-pamby
softness or indecision about any of them. "I will
like to do right, and then do as I like," might have
been the unspoken motto of every one. A will of
one's own is a precious heritage; not to be crushed,
or broken, or yielded up to anyone but the Divine
Master Himself.

lg.l: "Our wills are ours, we know not how,
Our wills are ours, to make them Thine."

div1.p:
Some are fitted by God only to follow and obey
those more capable than themselves. Then by all
means let these submit with cheerfulness and yield
willing obedience; their services will thus be of incalculable
value. But those who move the world,
and leave an impress for good upon future generations,
are persons of strong convictions and distinct
individuality, who, having first learned to control
themselves, may safely undertake to command others.
If any of us are conscious of possessing a strong will,
let us not regard it as a defect, or something to get
rid of; let us ask God to sanctify and guide it, then
it may prove a glorious gift and a means of service
to Him and those around us.

In conclusion, we would express our thanks first of
all to Miss Agnes Weston in affording us the means
of giving accurate particulars of her life and work,
both by permitting extracts from her collaborator,
Miss Wintz's interesting book, "Our Blue Jackets,"
and by kindly undertaking herself to correct statistics,
etc., up to the most recent date; and we also acknowledge
our indebtedness as regards the other
biographies to Miss Willard's "My Happy Half-Century;"
to the memoirs of "Sister Dora" by her
friends, Miss Lonsdale and Miss Ridsdale; and to
the life of Mrs. Booth by her son-in-law, Major Booth-Tucker,
of the Salvation Army.

If we succeed in inspiring any young reader with
a higher sense of the glorious possibilities of a
woman's ministry, our pleasant task will not have
been in vain.

div2.p:
Some children bring sunshine with them when
they come into the world, others find it waiting
for them; Frances Willard seems to have been
one of those few favoured mortals to whose share
falls the double portion of brightness—sunshine within
and without.

She was born—a longed-for and prayed-for little
daughter, to fill the aching void left by the early death
of a baby sister—on the 28th of September, 1839, at
Churchville, Monroe County, N.Y.

Her father was the son of Elijah Willard, a good
New England Puritan pastor, and descended from
the Willards who had lived at Horsmonden, in Kent,
for nearly six hundred years. He was a man of
somewhat severe mould, high-principled, cultured,
and intellectual, but suffering the life-long disadvantage
of weak physical health.

Mrs. Willard, on the other hand, was blessed with
abounding health and spirits, and a rarely lovely
disposition. Gifted in many ways beyond the average,
she was yet able to be cheery and contented in
circumstances that must often have been sorely
uncongenial to her. A poet at heart, her mind was
stored with gems from Cowper, Coleridge, Thomson,
and others of the same type. Her daughter has
recorded that her exquisitely expressive rendering of
Wordsworth's "Intimations of Immortality," even at
the advanced age of eighty-six, was beyond anything
she had elsewhere heard.

The tenderness and spirituality of Mrs. Willard's
character equalled its poetry, and although she did
not "talk religion" to her children, she taught them
of God's great goodness and beauty in all His works,
finding Him in every cloud, and flower, and chirping
bird; she made them "love the Heart that is at
Nature's heart," and when she prayed, she uttered
fewer petitions than thanksgivings. "Thou hast
done us only good," she would say. "Thou dost
brood over us as a mother-bird broods over her helpless
little ones." She taught her children gentle
manners, but she never restrained their healthy freedom;
she put everything in their way that was good,
best of all, a good example, but she never forced or
fretted them into following it.

Frances had a brother, Oliver, five years older than
herself, and a sister, Mary, who was three years
younger. Our heroine was a small and delicate child,
bright, clever, and affectionate, as one can easily
MISS WILLARDS'S EARLY HOME.
believe, but physically somewhat slow of development;
at fifteen she looked more like a girl of
twelve.

When she was two years old, the family removed
from Churchville to Oberlin, and again, when she was
seven, to "Forest Home," an isolated farmstead in
Wisconsin.

Here, for twelve happy years, the three young folks
lived with Nature. Their father was as passionate a
lover of trees and birds and flowers for their own
sakes as his wife was for the preciousness of their
revelation. He took his children about with him,
delighting to teach and interest them in all he
knew and cared for himself. Although a scholar and
a man of books, Mr. Willard was of so practical a
mind, that under his cultivation "Forest Home"
became in the course of years the prize farm of the
county. Here were sown in Frances' mind the seeds
of those temperance principles which were in later
years to influence the nation and the world; for no
alcoholic beverage of any sort did Mr. Willard allow
in his home, or to his field labourers, though a
pleasant "harvest drink," compounded of water,
molasses and ginger, was supplied to the latter in
abundance.

The three children were almost continually out of
doors; the girls as far as possible following and imitating
their big brother in all that he did. They spun
tops, they played marbles, they walked on stilts, they
climbed trees, they harnessed the horses and milked
the cows. They were not, however, allowed to ride.
But so great a deprivation did Frances—or "Frank"
to use her home name—feel this restriction to be, that
she did not rest satisfied until she had trained a young
heifer to wear a saddle and carry a rider!

It is enough to send town children into fits of
hopeless longing to read of the lovely times these
youngsters had, of the picnics in the woods, whither
a toothsome lunch was carried by the goat which
Mary possessed as an off-set to Frank's trained cow;
of their archery competitions; of the two oaks by the
homestead gate, in the branches of which each girl
had a snug seat fitted up, a sort of aerial "den" sacred
to herself, of the games in the big play-house that
was built for them when the barn was being put up
of the make-believe fights with "Injuns," and the
doings of "The Rustic Club."

These healthful recreations were not only tolerated
but actually helped forward by their wise and sympathetic
mother, who allowed each child to develop
according to his or her natural bent; while Mary
loved housewifely occupations, Frances took more
kindly to hammer and nails.

The Willards' nearest visiting neighbours lived
about a mile away; these were Mr. and Mrs. Hodge,
and their three boys. Mr. Hodge was a Yale College
graduate, and had been Latin tutor at Oberlin
College, and his wife, a gifted and cultured woman,
was Mrs. Willard's greatest friend. But as there were
no little girls of suitable age at the Hodges' home,
Frank and Mary Willard seem to have had their
games chiefly with themselves and their brother.

For indoor amusements they wrote diaries, "edited"
papers, drew, painted, and modeled in clay. The
laws enacted for the "city" which they planned
round and about "Forest Home," and the rules of "The
Artists" and "The Rustic Club," which they also
inaugurated, show a remarkable gift for organising on
the part of these bright young people. The city, we
may remark ("Fort City" was its name) was to have
no drinking-saloons. no billiard halls, and of course
would require no jail. But whether it ever reached
a further stage of development than the laying out of
"Broadway" in front of the farmstead gate, by means
of digging out with a fire-shovel and paving with
bricks and pebbles, and the election of the city
officials, history does not relate.

There was something of Puritanical strictness in the
way the Sabbath was kept at "Forest Home"; yet such
were the simple and natural conditions of life there,
that even this does not seem to have pressed hardly
upon the children. No work was to be done, of even
the most trivial nature, on that day, no books read
except such as were of a decidedly religious character,
and no calls made or received. This latter precaution
seems to have been somewhat unnecessary, for, as
Frances says, "there was nobody to come but the
birds, and nowhere to go except to the fields and
pastures." For the rest, the girls went to church in
the town of Janesville every Sunday morning, with
their elders by turns, either Mr. Willard, Mrs. Willard,
or Oliver always staying at home to mind house and
cook the delicious Sunday dinner, which, religious
rules notwithstanding, was an institution at "Forest
Home."

Later in the day, Mr. Willard thought it no wrong
to take his little girls for a pleasant stroll in the
pasture, or by the broad, tree-shaded river. Frances,
as fond of her jack-knife as any boy, was, however, on
these occasions allowed to "whittle" only, the fashioning
of whistles, or any other of the objects she was so
skilful at carving, being for the day prohibited.

On the Sabbath evenings, attendance at Divine
worship a second time being precluded by the distance—about
four miles—of this prairie farm from
the church, the parents and children would gather
together to sing simple old-fashioned hymns from the
Methodist hymn-book. Needless to say, Bible-reading
and prayers were part of the daily life of the family,
but the children were not by any means pushed, much
less goaded, into the paths of righteousness; Mrs.
Willard believed firmly in prayer, example, and
natural development It was her oft-expressed conviction
that every one receives "according to their
faith."

The heroine of our sketch was not a pattern of early
piety according to conventional ideas. From her
infantile days it was instinctive in her, when told
anything about God or revelation, to ask "How do
you know?" She strongly objected to be talked to
on the subject of religion, and was too shy to allow
anyone, except perhaps her dearly-loved sister, Mary,
to guess when she was even deeply moved. Yet faith
and love were surely growing, though hidden, in her
childish heart, for years afterwards she remembered
stretching out her hand towards the blue sky as she
lay on the grass by the river-bank, and saying to her
sister, "See there! could you resist a hand that so
much wanted to clasp your own? Of course you
couldn't, and God cannot, either. I believe that,
though I do not see, He reaches down to me."

The love between Frances and Mary, as well as
between the girls and their kind, good-natured big
brother, Oliver, was very great. Frances was ardent
and affectionate, Mary, gentle and sweet. Mary's
conscience was exceedingly tender, at one time almost
morbidly so, but Frank's more vigorous mind helped
to balance that of the younger girl. Mutually they
agreed to the lovely custom of asking each other's
forgiveness, just before going to sleep at night, for
anything during the day which had been not quite
sisterly and kind, and thanking one another for all
that had been good. "I ask your forgiveness and
thank you," was the abbreviated formula, to which the
answer was, "I freely forgive you, and welcome."
This habit was kept up until, after "nineteen beautiful
years," came the final "good-night" of sweet Mary's
life on earth, and her sister "asked her forgiveness
and thanked her" for the last time.

Studying from books formed but a small item in
the lives of these "prairie flowers" until Frances was
twelve years old. Frances actually could not write
her name until she was nine; a little desultory learning
of lessons and practising of pot-hooks and hangers
on winter evenings under their mother's supervision
being all the schooling to which they were subjected.
But at length, much to their delight, it was arranged
that an accomplished young lady, a Miss Burdick,
daughter of Colonel Burdick who had recently come
to reside in the neighbourhood, should teach them
daily in their own home, with the two daughters of
another neighbour for companions.

The girls rushed to the joys of study with the
keenest zest—their brother had already, for two winters
been attending an academy in Janesville—and in one
year, we are assured, learned as much as "little ones
are tormented into, now, during seven"! The diaries
which they both kept, and Frances' early poems, are
sufficient proof that this assertion is not an exaggerated
one.

Miss Burdick, though only eighteen years old, was a
goddess in the eyes of these little rustic maidens;
she taught them singing, drawing, and botany, as well
as more prosaic accomplishments; she was not a
teacher only, but a dearly-loved companion and
friend, and to her Frances confided some of her own
longings and aspirations. For by this time the girl's
future work was already foreshadowing itself in her
yearning, unsuggested by anyone, to write for the
press, and even "to speak in public, if she dared."
Strange to say, a prophetic instinct, even at thirteen
years old, was whispering to Frances Willard that
something quite out of the common lot awaited her,
and she was wont to tell Miss Burdick that she knew
she was "born to a fate." This was no mere youthful
bumptiousness, but, we believe, as solemn a calling
from Heaven as that of Samuel of old; and in the same
spirit of obedience as his, the child lying on the prairie
grass would lift her hands towards the sky and say
in her inmost heart, "What is it—what is it that I am
to be, O God?"

After two years of "play-school" with Miss Burdick,
Mr. Willard and his friend, Mr. Inman, the father of
the girls' fellow-scholars, succeeded in getting a small
district school-house built about a mile from "Forest
Home," and here, according to American custom, were
soon assembled most of the young folks of the
neighbourhood, boys and girls, gentle and simple,
under one roof, to benefit by the instructions of Mr.
Hodge, now "Professor," who had accepted the post
of teacher, and as a graduate of Yale College was well
equipped for his task.

This gentleman, who was an Englishman by birth,
and rejoiced in the patriotic Christian name of Nelson
Wellington, seems to have been an excellent tutor,
but he was replaced after four months by his wife's
sister, Mrs. Hovey, whose brightness, geniality, and
aptitude to teach "made school just like a play-day"
to her fortunate pupils.

But we must linger no longer over Frances Willard's
childish days. The last teacher she and her sister
had at "Forest Home" was their mother's accomplished
sister Sarah, who came on a visit to the prairie farm
when Frances was in her early teens; and after her
departure, the girls, whose appetites for learning had
been keenly whetted, gave their father little peace
until he consented to let them go to college.

head.hi:
CHAPTER II.
"WHERE THE BROOK AND RIVER MEET."

div2.p:
In the spring of 1857, Frances, having been by this
time unwillingly introduced to hairpins, and
inducted into a "hateful new gown" with a long
skirt, that precluded all future possibilities of fence-jumping
and tree-climbing, went with her sister to
Milwaukee Female College, where their Aunt Sarah,
mentioned above, was one of the leading teachers.

Ere this, however, our heroine had gained her
earliest public distinction as winner of the first prize—
a silver medal and a "lovely cup"—offered by the
Illinois Agricultural Society for the best essay on
"The Embellishment of a Country Home," for
which she had taken her own beautiful home as a
model.

She was a restless, adventurous spirit, and much as
she loved her kindred with the whole strength of an
intensely affectionate nature, the girl longed for a
wider horizon and fuller scope for her powers.

Mrs. Willard had said—and the words are worth
writing in letters of gold:—"To be busy doing something
that is worthy to be done is the happiest thing
in all this world for girl or boy, for old or young." So
to content her daughter's active mind, opportunities
for an advanced course of study were provided, and
for a time proved all-sufficient.

The remarkable freedom and independence of
Frances' nature was demonstrated when, on her
eighteenth birthday—her "coming of age" according
to the American standard—she being at home for the
vacation after her first college term, she coolly commenced
reading "Ivanhoe" before her father's face.

He was at first inclined to be indignant, novels of
every description being contraband in "Forest Home";
but when his daughter gravely and respectfully
asserted her newly attained right to do what seemed
good in her own eyes, he laughed, and contested the
point no more.

In the spring of 1858, Frances and Mary commenced
study at the North-Western Female College,
Evanston, near Chicago, the best educational establishment
for women at that time known.

While here, the elder girl was a cause of some
anxiety to Professor Jones, the President of the
College, who was an earnest Christian, by her apparently
pronounced sceptical tendencies. Revival
meetings took place during her first College term, but
after once being over-persuaded by this well-meaning
gentleman to go with others "to the altar"—which
we take to be something analogous to the "penitent
form" of Salvation Army fame—the girl's natural
honesty asserted itself so far as to prompt her to write
the Professor a letter, begging to be excused from
taking part in any more of such demonstrations until
inwardly conscious of a change of heart.

In this letter she wrote: "If there is a God, a
heaven, a hell, a devil, then I am undone. I have
been taught to think that all these exist, yet from
childhood I have doubted."

Nevertheless, at the same period, the same girl
penned these words in her diary:—"I thank God
most that He has made us so that we may make
ourselves great, wise, and good, that we may change
ourselves in mind from helpless babes to strong,
steadfast characters."

No wonder that Professor Jones concluded presently
that her "scepticism was of a mild form. Most of all,
she doubted all her doubts."

"What a queer girl Frank Willard is!" said one of
her companions to him. "She won't confess that she
knows or believes anything. She says she doesn't
know whether there is a God, and she doesn't know
whether the Bible is true; she is trying to find
out."

"Don't be distressed, Mattie," the wise man replied.
"If she will only keep on trying to find out, she will
find out. All her friends have to do is to pray that
she may persevere."

It was while pursuing her ordinary course of study
that light came, and Wayland's "Moral Science,"
which she was reading in preparation for an examination,
was, under God, the means of Frances Willard's
conversion. On a blank half-page of that volume,
her good friend, Professor Jones, was one day overjoyed
to find this memorandum written by her to
meet his eye:—"When I began this study I could
not say whether there was a God or no—and if
there was, whether He cared for me or not. Now,
thanks to President Wayland and my faithful
instructors, I can say from my heart I believe that
there is a God, and that He is my Father."

Shortly after, the brave and earnest-hearted girl
voluntarily made her public confession of faith—not
under the excitement and pressure of a revival
meeting, but on one quiet Sunday evening, when,
the pastor having at the close of an ordinary service
asked any who wished to unite with the church on
probation to meet him at the altar, she alone of the
whole congregation responded.

This was the beginning of a steady Christian life,
which deepened, brightened, and unfolded year by year.

As a school-girl, Frances was popular both on
account of her intellectual gifts and her buoyant
spirits. A companion of these college days—afterwards
a dearly-loved sister-in-law—says: "It was
but a few weeks till she was editor of the College
paper, and leader of all the intellectual forces among
the students.… She was an inventor of sport, and
her ingenuity devised many an amusement which
was not all amusement, but which involved considerable
exercise of wit and intelligence—and our beloved
Professor soon found that he could always rely upon
her influence in the school to counteract the tendency
to silly escapades and moonlight walks with the
University boys.… If one of those school-mates
had been called upon to sum up in a sentence a
rough estimate of her friend, she would probably at
this period have given as her opinion, 'She's the
leader of all sport among the girls, and doesn't care a
snap for the boys.'"

Early in the autumn of 1858 the Willard family
let their beloved "Forest Home," and removed to
Evanston, Mrs. Willard, from certain revelations made
by Frances as to the temptations of college life, fearing
to let her daughters be so far from their parents'
oversight and care.

The last year at school was one of great strain for
the ardent young student, and she twice broke down
in health before graduation—the goal of her ambitions
—was triumphantly reached. This, however, was
attained in the summer of 1859, and passionately as
she loved learning, and affectionately as she regarded
both teachers and class-mates, such was Frances'
natural repugnance to rule and restraint, that she said
farewell to college life with joy.

The diary of Frances Willard's first year out of
school is full of such noble aspirations and desires as
we should expect to be the flower-buds of the life
that followed. Particularly did she yearn to become
more loving and gentle, and to be of use and comfort
in the world.

"Ask the mighty, infinite Helper," she exhorts
herself in a written soliloquy, "to model you by His
plans, let them be what they will, so that every year
you may grow 'calmer and calmer,' richer in love and
peacefulness, and forgetting the poor dreams of less
thoughtful years, have this, and this only, for your
ambition: to be gentle, kindly, and forgiving, full of
charity which suffereth long, and patience which is
pleasing in the sight of God and man."

And again:—"I have resolved that neither public
opinion, nor narrow-minded pride, nor any other
creature, shall prevent me from showing, whenever
I can, kindness as delicate and respect as genuine as
I know how, to those whom the community, as a rule,
treats slightingly or with positive neglect. If I do
this, I shall be of value to the world, whether the
world knows it or not. I shall, I think, bring some
happiness into troubled and wounded hearts, and, oh,
will it not be sweet to remember in the hour when
I shall most need comfort, the hour in which I am to
die!"

But the young eaglet could not be quiet for long in
the home nest. Frances' inborn love of freedom and
variety, not by any means to be confused with
changeableness or fickleness, prompted her once more
to crave to be on the wing. Anticipating opposition
from her father, who was well able to support her in
comfort, and did not consider that women ought to
want to earn money, she did the deed on her own
responsibility, and confessed afterwards. She accepted
the post of teacher at a small school-house on the
borders of the prairie, some ten miles from home.

Here, at the village of Harlem, she tried her
'prentice hand on some very rough material, and first
learned what home-sickness meant. Still a child in
heart and nature, she pathetically confided to her
diary her earnest resolutions "not to cry" over her
difficulties, but to remember her age. But she seems
all the while to be conscious of weakness or undevelopment
of character, which she heroically set herself to
remedy.

"I am twenty years old," she writes, "and I have
neither dignity nor womanliness.… I am neither
self-reliant nor self-contained.… I have never been
out in the world, have had no care or trouble, no grief
worth mentioning, no 'lovyer,' as my brother says,
nor any love affair to sober me.… I see clearly
that I shall never be the grown-up person that I ought
to be until I have borne sorrows and had cares."

Poor little girl! A greater sorrow than she ever
dreamed possible was slowly but surely creeping
towards her along the sunny path of the future.

After a few months' experience at Harlem, followed
by a holiday at home, Frances went as assistant
teacher to an academy at the town of Kankakee,
about sixty miles from Chicago, but owing to the
urgent wishes of her parents, remained there only one
term.

In the spring of 1861 she taught Harlem school
again for a few weeks, and in the following year,
living at home, she was employed at the public
school of Evanston. It was about this period that
Miss Willard was secretly engaged for some months
to a young divinity student named Fowler. Years
later, she expressed a wish that this little romance
might be made known after her death, as she "believed
it might contribute to a better understanding between
good men and women."

This engagement was entered into "on the supposition
that an intellectual comradeship was sure to
deepen into unity of heart." But the young couple
discovered in time that they were really too much
alike for mutual happiness, both displaying marked
strength of character and natural powers of leadership.
In consequence, this love affair, the only
episode of its kind, we believe, which occurred in the
life of the charming woman of whom Mr. Stead has
said that "women loved and men adored her" came
to an untimely end, and Frances Willard's spirit
remained free to the last of her days.

In June, 1862, came the first great sorrow of our
heroine's life.

We have not had space in this brief memoir to
accord more than a passing mention to that lovely
young sister whose brief biography Miss Willard
herself has so touchingly told in "Nineteen Beautiful
Years." But the record of an almost cloudless childhood
and girlhood closes with those three heart-break-ing
words in Frances' diary, "Mary is dead," and the
sun never shone for her with undimmed radiance
again.

head.hi:
CHAPTER III.
MISS WILLARD AS A TEACHER.

div2.p:
Shortly after the death of Mary Willard, the
Evanston home was broken up, Mr. and Mrs.
Willard going first to Janesville and then to Chicago,
and Oliver, their son, who married in July, 1862,
settling in Denver, Colorado. Frances for a time
taught the natural sciences at the North-Western
Female College, but was getting into a very low and
listless state of both mind and body, when a friend,
the wife of Bishop Simpson, rescued her out of it by
the proposition, backed by the offer of the Bishop
himself, that she should try her fortune at the Pittsburg
Female College, of which he was President on
the Board of Trustees.

Nothing particularly worthy of record here seems
to have taken place during the months spent at
Pittsburg. The diaries of this time are deeply tinged
with the sadness of bereavement and loneliness.
"I have the feeling," she writes, "of one who walks
blindfold among scenes too awful for his nerves to
bear, in the midst of which we eat and drink, wash
our faces, and complain that the fire won't burn in the
grate, or that the tea-bell doesn't ring in season.…
We are like a spider's web in some remote angle of
St Peter's Cathedral. I suppose the cunning insects
flurry greatly if a gnat flies past without being
entrapped! All that appertains to the building from
floor to dome is accidental in their sight."

On her return to her father and mother and Evanston
in the summer vacation, Frances busied herself in
writing that memoir of her sister to which we have
already alluded. The manuscript, when finished,
she herself carried to New York, under the escort of
one of her father's friends, Mr. Willard's old-world
notions as to the undesirability of publicity for women
once more being overborne by his go-ahead and
independent-spirited daughter. On her way thither,
Frances saw the Falls of Niagara, and congratulates
herself that she "did not drop into poetry, nor yet
into prose, in the presence of that gleaming mystery."

The winter of 1865 finds the subject of our monograph
teaching the Grove School at Evanston, a select
establishment founded by Mr. Edward Haskin, chiefly
for the benefit of his own six children. Miss Willard's
pupils here were "the best-born and best-mannered
children at Evanston, kindly, quick-witted, and
studious," and among them she first tried her disciplinary
plan of "The Bank of Character."

The method was this. She opened an account with
each student in her room, and put down certain
balances in his favour. "Then by a system of cards
of different values, which were interchangeable, as are
our bank notes of different denominations, that is,
one of a higher value being equivalent to several of a
lower denomination, the plan was carried out. Every
absence, tardiness, failure in recitation, case of whispering,
was subtracted from the bank account; and
so emulous were those children, that my tallest boys
were as much on the qui vive to know their standing
as were their youngest brothers."

In speaking of this time in after years, Miss Willard
adds:—"As I grow older, however, I doubt more and
more the propriety of offering prizes. Competition is
so fierce in this country and age, and the 'set' of
children's brains is so strong towards it from the first,
that I have become an ardent believer in co-operation
as a principle destined some day to overthrow the
selfishness of competition, and, with my present views,
would hardly re-enact the scenes that made the 'last
day' so exciting at that school."

In the spring of 1866, owing to the development of
the public school enterprise, Grove School, though
eminently successful, ceased to exist, and once again
Frances Willard went among strangers.

This time the scene of her labours was the town of
Lima, Livingston Co., N.Y., and she was accompanied
by her friend, Miss Kate Jackson, for whom she had
secured the promise of French classes in the same
place.

Here she seems to have been very comfortable, for
she wrote, after the confession, which to us, looking
at her history as a whole, is scarcely needed, that she
was "an inveterate lover of variety":—"My life is a
free and happy one—surfacely so. How strangely
accommodating are our natures! With nothing just
as I wish it; with chasms and voids in my life too
numerous to name, I yet have a good time, and no
complaint to make."

Still, "Change is our portion here" might have
been the burden of Miss Willard's song. The greater
part of 1867 was spent at home, helping to nurse her
father in his long, last illness.

He died in January, 1868, full of joy and peace,
and soon after this second bereavement, Frances
willingly agreed to the proposal of her friend, Kate
Jackson, that the two should together make the tour
of Europe at the expense of the latter.

Thus it came about that for the next two years our
heroine had the pleasure and advantage of traveling
and studying abroad. The pair went through nearly
every European country; northward "as far as Helsingfors,
Finland; east as far as the Volga banks in
Russia, and Damascus in Syria; making the tour of
Palestine, and going south far enough to look over
into Nubia on earth, and up into the Southern Cross
in the heavens."

While in Paris, Miss Willard studied under Guizot
the younger, Laboulaye, and Chevalier.

It was very soon after her return that Miss Willard
was induced to make her first attempt at lecturing in
public. A gentleman who had heard her relate, at
the meetings of the Women's Foreign. Missionary
Society at Chicago, some of her experiences in Egypt
and the Holy Land, was struck with her evident gift
for public speaking, and begged her to get up a
lecture, for the success of which he would take the
responsibility, offering her fifty dollars as prepayment.

Much as Miss Willard had longed for such an
opportunity, she felt, now it had arrived, a little
"By all means, my child, accept; enter every open
door." So, for the next few weeks, Frances was
busily engaged writing and committing to memory a
lecture on the subject that was nearest to her heart—
that of the right of woman to "a fair chance to be all
that God gave her power to be,"

She called this lecture "The New Chivalry," and it
was a great success, winning most flattering notices
from the Chicago press.

The next important event in our heroine's life was
her election to the position of President of the new
Women's College at Evanston.

This institution, in which was merged the "North-Western
Female College," where the sisters Willard
had graduated some years before, was to be a thorough
woman's college, "in which women should constitute
the Board of Trustees, a woman should be president
and confer diplomas, and women should be, for the
first time, recognized and proved as the peers of men
in administrative power."

It was opened in 1872, and here Miss Willard
further developed her "Bank of Character" system
of maintaining order. Filled with an instinctive abhorrence
of rules and regulations herself, she heartily
sympathised with girls of similarly independent spirit,
and organised on their behalf her "Roll of Honour"
and "Self-Governed" Societies.

The basis of this mode of discipline was, as she
explained to parents and guardians, that "rules are
for the unruly and regulations for the irregular," and
the condition of being "not under the law, but under
grace," the goal to be aimed at by every scholar. The
ideal set before each pupil was, "Just be a Christian
Lady."

One month's absolute freedom from any occasion
for reproof entitled a girl to have her name inscribed
upon the Roll of Honour, and to be "invested with
certain powers and responsibilities usually restricted
to the faculty." After one entire term upon the Roll
of Honour, uninterrupted by a single misdemeanour,
she would be promoted to the ranks of the "Self-Governed,"
whose honours and privileges were, of
course, proportionately greater.

The success of this original experiment was proved
by the fact that at the end of one year twelve girls
were on the Self-Governed List, and all the others
upon the Roll of Honour.

These were joyous days for the bright and dearly-loved
President, who has herself laid it down as an
axiom that "the highest form of human occupation
is doing good according to a plan."

She had all the young ladies, numbering several
hundreds, in her English Composition classes, one
popular feature of which was reporting for the Chicago
and Evanston papers; she lectured to her Art classes
with the aid of numbers of beautiful photographic and
stereoscopic views which she and Miss Jackson had
brought home with them from their European travels;
she opened and closed her recitations with a few
words of prayer; a missionary society was organised
in the College, and a short daily prayer-meeting,
though voluntary, was "overwhelmingly attended."

One of her pupils at that time, afterwards the wife
of a college president, thus says:—"In the most
important part of her work as an educator—the
development of character—I can speak from the most
intimate knowledge. In this I doubt if she ever had
a superior, and but for Arnold of Rugby I should
have said, an equal. Her power over the girls who
came under her influence was most extraordinary.
It is an amusing fact that some people regarded it
with a mixture of wonder and fear as something a
little allied to witchcraft—an inexplicable spell not
founded on reason."
But this halcyon period was too bright to last.

Dr. Haven, with whom, as President of the North-Western
University, Miss Willard had so unanimously
worked, was elected to fill another position, and his
place was taken by the Rev. Dr. Fowler.

This gentleman did not entirely sympathise with
Miss Willard's views as to "self-government," and
friction was caused which eventually resulted in our
heroine feeling that resignation of her appointment
was her only course.

This, which she called the "greatest sacrifice" her
life had known, or even could know, was made, after
due deliberation and much anguish of spirit, in the
summer of 1874, and its immediate outcome was the
opening of the way for the greatest work of Frances
Willard's life.

The year 1874 was memorable in Chicago as
witnessing the commencement and growth of
the Women's Temperance Crusade, and it was not
long after Frances cut herself adrift from her work at
Evanston University that, her anti-liquor sympathies
being well known, she was offered and accepted the
post of corresponding secretary to the Women's
Christian Temperance Union.

Her first practical connection with the crusade was
when, in Pittsburg, she walked with the procession
of women, many of them ladies of birth and culture,
who undertook to visit every drinking-saloon in the
city, and sing hymns and pray outside its doors, or
inside, if allowed.

On this occasion, the leader of the band having read
a psalm at the bar of a saloon they had been permitted
to enter, Miss Willard was requested by her,
after the singing of the "Rock of Ages," to offer up
prayer; and she there and then knelt down in the
sawdust on the floor, and feeling "not the least reluctance,"
prayed more truly than she had ever done
in her life before, except perhaps, she says, at her
sister Mary's dying bed.

This was Miss Willard's "crusade baptism;" soon
after she was appointed president of the Chicago
W.C.T.U.

Declining the pecuniary assistance offered her, she,
fired by the example of St. Francis d'Assisi, whom she
greatly admired, for some months endeavoured to hold
this position entirely without salary, dependent for her
daily bread upon the small collections which were
occasionally taken at her lectures, etc.

Her mother, though she did not entirely approve
of this mendicant-friar business, did not first discourage
her daughter's romantic method; may we
hint that, perhaps she knew from experience that
opposition would have been of little use. But by-and-by
when Frances went home, literally half-starved,
almost shoeless, and downright ill from over-work
and privation, she talked common-sense to her in the
following strain:—

"I believe in faith as much as you do, but you
have, with pure intention, yet ignorantly, flown in the
face of Providence. Those good women spoke to you
about a maintenance the very day they chose you
president. That was your Heavenly Father's kind
provision, and you turned away from it, and dictated
to Him the method of His care.… God isn't going
to start loaves of bread flying down the chimney, nor
set the fire going in my stove without fuel. I shall
soon see the bottom of my flour-barrel and coal-bin.
"SHE KNELT DOWN IN THE SAWDUST ON THE FLOOR."
Now write to those temperance women a plain statement
of facts, and tell them that you have made the
discovery that God works by means, and they may
help you if they like."

Frances' letter to her comrades produced at once a
loving response, with a cheque for 100 dollars enclosed.
She saw her mistake; nevertheless, she
always maintained that the period of her somewhat
quixotic "faith test" was the loveliest and most
blessed of her whole life. "I enjoyed the episode,"
she writes, "and shall be the better and richer for it
evermore."

After working, writing, and speaking for two years
in the interest of the Chicago (now advanced to the
National) W.C.T.U., it was borne in upon Miss
Willard's mind that she was to "speak for woman's
ballot, as a weapon of protection to her home and
tempted loved ones from the tyranny of drink;" and
she at once proposed to colleagues that her she should
do so.

The idea was, however, met at first with much
opposition. As one influential lady said, "We do
not purpose to trail our skirts through the mire of
politics."

In 1877, Miss Willard went to Washington, and
there spoke before the House Committee on Judiciary,
"urging the claims of the Home Protection Petition
adopted at Newark, asking that, in the territories and
the District of Columbia, the sale of alcoholic drinks
should be legalised only 'when the majority of men
by their votes, and women by their signatures, should
ask for the legalising of such sale.'"

On her return to Chicago she undertook to go with
the famous evangelist, Dwight L. Moody, to Boston,
and help him with the women's meetings there.

In this cultured city Miss Willard held a daily
Bible-reading for women, sometimes with an attendance
of a thousand or even fourteen hundred persons;
and once she actually preached in Mr. Moody's tabernacle
on a Sunday afternoon. Here also she became
acquainted with Miss Bessie Gordon, and her sister,
Anna, who was destined to be Miss Willard's companion
and secretary for many subsequent years.

All went well, until our heroine was taken to task
by the evangelist for appearing on a temperance
platform with a lady who was known to hold Unitarian
views.

Miss Willard was too large of heart and broad
of mind to submit readily to such a restriction as this.
She wrote to him, after due consideration, a letter on
the subject, of which this is the gist—"I fail to see
that it is for us to decide who shall work in this cause
side by side with us, and who shall not I cannot
judge how the hearts of earnest, pure, prayerful
women may appear in God's clear sight"

This liberality of thought reminds us of her reply
to the question whether she condemned theatres, or
those who go to them. "I do not condemn anyone,"
she said, "who with a clear and enlightened conscience
goes anywhere."

Once again, as many times before and after,
Miss Willard found that she must, in following the
dictates of her own judgment run counter to the
advice of some of her most valued friends. These
thought that in disconnecting herself from Mr.
Moody she was letting slip a splendid opportunity
for extending the work of the W.C.T.U. But their
arguments were of no avail. Freedom—that liberty
of thought, speech, and action which she was ever
ready to fight for and accord to others—was to
Frances Willard as the breath of life. "The jacket,"
she writes (of Mr. Moody's theological interpretations)
"was too straight. I could not wear it."

It was in 1877, at the Annual Convention at
Chicago, that the now world-famed "white ribbon"
was first adopted as the badge of the W.C.T.U., the
colour being emblematic of purity and peace, on the
principle of "first pure, then peaceable."

At the same Convention, Miss Willard for a time
resigned the corresponding secretaryship of this
Society, owing to the nomination of an alternative
candidate for the post, a greatly respected friend of her
own, whom she did not choose to oppose. But the
following year the White Ribbon Regiment of Illinois
placed her at its head, and entering at once upon
their Home Protection campaign, they in nine weeks
collected nearly two hundred thousand signatures to a
petition that women should be accorded the privilege
of voting when the question of licensing the sale of
intoxicating drinks was being anywhere discussed.

This petition produced no effect upon the legislature,
but it so aroused the people, that out of 832
towns voting that spring under the local option law,
625 declared themselves for prohibition, which the
White Ribboners felt to be worth striving for.

Just about this period came a third severed bereavement
upon Miss Willard, very suddenly, in the death,
after only a day or two of apparently slight indisposition,
of her beloved brother, Oliver.

This gentleman, "of whose great gifts and genial
nature," writes his sister, "I can never say enough,"
had for some years occupied the responsible position
of editor, first of the Chicago Mail,and afterwards of
the Chicago Post.

The news of his death was conveyed in a telegram
to Miss Willard just as she was preparing to conduct
a temperance prayer-meeting at the town of Saginaw,
Michigan, which she was visiting at the time. It
would be impossible for her to get a train for Chicago
until an hour which would permit of the fulfilment of
her engagement first, if she so desired, and thinking,
"He would have wished me to do this," the heroic
woman mastered her first passion of grief sufficiently
to go to the prayer-meeting as appointed, where
she and her audience, whom she told of her sorrow,
"cried together, praying and talking of a better life,
which is a heavenly."

On returning home, Miss Willard at once took
upon herself, with her widowed sister-in-law, the task
of continuing the superintendence of the editors,
reporters, proof-readers, compositors, etc., a force of
more than sixty persons in all, who were engaged in
the production of the Chicago Evening Post.

It was a stupendous undertaking for two women,
neither of whom possessed any editorial experience,
and, in spite of all their hard work and energy, it had,
in a short time, to be relinquished, and stands out
conspicuously in Miss Willard's history as the only
positive failure among all her efforts.

After this, she started on a Temperance tour in the
South, where having, as a Northerner, been prepared
for somewhat scant sympathy, she was amazed and
delighted by the cordiality of her reception; indeed, it
would appear from the records of that royal progress
through nearly one hundred towns and cities of the
South, that the people were even more readily responsive
to the appeals of Miss Willard and her helpers
than in the more cool-blooded and beer-ridden North.
She felt that the breach left by the war between the
two halves of the great American continent could be
by nothing so well bridged over as by the uniting
of the temperance men of both North and South in
voting for the prohibition of the liquor traffic.

In 1881, Miss Willard resolved to identify herself
unreservedly with the Prohibition party, whether
composed mainly of Republicans or Democrats.
Although hitherto her sympathies had been staunchly
Republican, she now felt that the cause of Home
Protection and the Prohibition of the drink traffic
was of greater moral importance than anything else,
and, with many others of similar convictions, she
retired from the Republican party to become a
member of the Central committee of the newly reorganised
"Prohibition Home Protection Party."
In her official address to the W.C.T.U. she eloquently
pleaded with its members to throw the whole weight
of their influence into the same balance.

Much time and energy in 1883 were expended by
Miss Willard in completing the visitation of every
one of the forty-eight States in the Union, with every
town therein which had, according to the census of
1870, 10,000 inhabitants, and many much smaller ones.

This grand tour was finished in the autumn of the
above year, an event which was celebrated at Detroit
with great rejoicings.

Then another expansion of the W.C.T.U. was
decided upon, and it became the "World's Woman's
Christian Temperance Union," of which gigantic
Union Miss Willard in due course became President,
a position she held until her death. The ramifications
of this great force were extended by degrees
to Australia, India, China, Madeira, Madagascar,
Siam, Straits Settlements, Corea, Japan, and, in fact,
everywhere.

During the next few years Miss Willard's life is
the story of a noble, persistent struggle on the part
of herself and the Union which she represented, to
gain the ear and the sympathy of the legislature.
Meetings were held, speeches made, petitions framed
at every possible opportunity. But smaller matters
relating to the freedom and welfare of home and
woman, were not overlooked; as an example, witness
the petition adopted by the St Louis Convention
and sent to the editors of fashion-papers, begging
them to discountenance in their pages such plates
as represented and encouraged unnatural constriction
of the waist, and lend their "aid toward the elevation
of woman to a more perfect physical estate" by
making the figures depicted "conform more nearly
to the normal standard and the conditions requisite
for the maintenance of health."

Miss Willard was always an earnest advocate of
the duty of endeavouring to preserve a sound body
as the garment of a sound mind. Busy as was her
life she contrived to maintain a wise regularity of
habit, which, considering her natural delicacy of
physique, probably contributed not a little towards
the lengthening of her life until a fair middle age,
while both her sister and her brother, doubtless
inheriting with her their father's weakness of constitution,
died without numbering half their days.

"My rising-hour," she writes, "has long been from
seven to half-past (I wish it were earlier!) and retiring
anywhere from half-past seven to half-past nine; but
when travelling, it has been about ten. I regard
that hour as the dead line of recuperation, vigour,
and sustained mental activity. Eight hours of
writing and study, all of them between breakfast
and tea, has been my rule. After the evening meal
at six o'clock I will not work—lecturing, of course,
excepted. I expect, as a rule, to sit at my desk from
8.30 or 9 a.m. until 6 p.m. daily, with a half-hour's
interval from 12.30 to 1, and an outing; of about half-an-hour
I never touch the pen after tea, and ten
o'clock finds our house dark as a pocket, silent as
a tomb, and restful as a cradle."

It is a noteworthy fact that Miss Willard never
in all her life suffered from insomnia. She calls
herself "one of the seven sleepers," and even in the
trying and exciting days of endeavouring to keep up
her brother's newspaper, the anxiety never deprived
her of her ability to rest at night.

It was in 1891 that our heroine first became
acquainted with Lady Henry Somerset, from
thenceforward to be her dear friend and valued
coadjutor.

Lady Henry was visiting America in her official
capacity of President of the British Women's
Temperance Association, and was introduced to
Miss Willard by the well-known Quakeress preacher
and writer, Hannah Whittall Smith.

This lady greatly desired her two much admired
friends to be acquainted, and attempted to pave the
way by praising each of them to the other in a generous,
but perhaps hardly judicious fashion, for Lady
Henry quietly remarked when Frances Willard's
virtues and attractiveness were being thus extolled,
that "much-praised people were usually disappointing."
However, the English lady shortly after had
an opportunity of meeting the American in the flesh,
and, said the Quakeress afterwards," They had not
been together five minutes before I saw they were
made for each other; both were delighted, and so
was I."

Lady Henry Somerset has herself thus described
that meeting:—

"In October, 1891, I stood for the first time on
the platform of the railway station in the 'classic
town' of Evanston. I had only landed in America
a few weeks, but my steps were naturally bent to the
Mecca of White Ribboners. … Like all Temperance
women, good and true, I had placed Miss Willard's
image in my inmost shrine; and yet as the train
glided towards Evanston, I felt that our idols seem
made to be shattered, and this one also might possibly
shortly be dashed to the ground. On the platform
she awaited my coming—a delicate, fragile figure,
in a pretty blue dress, her small hand shading her
eyes as she looked about attentively seeking her
guest, and as she came toward me I saw a face so
kind and frank that it seemed as though the peaceful
simplicity of childhood had somehow remained unruffled
by the chilling blasts of life. … From that
hour I have felt that we were friends—friends not
only to joy in each other's companionship, but in that
truer sense that binds souls."

The following year, Miss Willard came to England
as the guest of her new friend, and in the grounds of
Reigate Priory, being then fifty-three years of age,
she mastered the bicycle presented to her by Lady
Henry, as she had been recommended physical
exercise along with mental rest. The various stages
of her progress towards the accomplishment of this
by no means easy task, are described most entertainingly
and with thoughtful little moral lessons
deduced therefrom, in Miss Willard's booklet, "A
Wheel within a Wheel."

Every summer after that, until 1896, the "Uncrowned
Queen" of the United States, as owing to
her immense influence over the people of her own
country she has been not inappropriately called, paid
a visit to Lady Somerset's charming home. In
January, 1893, she received a public and most enthusiastic
welcome to this country, and every year
she became better known and more warmly loved on
this side of the Atlantic.

An Englishwoman—" One who knew her," thus
writes:—"In five minutes I was fairly conquered by
Miss Willard's gracious, genial, simple manner. …
At the bottom of her captivating manner lay a great
belief in the goodness of human nature. People
turned their best side to her, much as a flower turns
to the sun. … Her humour constantly bubbled over.
She looked over her gold pince-nez, a glint in her
fine blue eyes, and uttered some quaint conceit in
her quiet way, much amusing the company. Nor
was she one of those who are only bright and witty
in society; to get her alone was quite a treat, for she
always gave of her best".

As regards the financial success of Miss Willard's
life, concerning which some may feel curious, she has
in her autobiography thus recorded:—" Though I
have earned tens of thousands of dollars, I have
nothing except Rose Cottage, the joint inheritance
of my mother and myself, and finally to revert, after
a tenure of 'life use,' to the National W.C.T.U.; to
be employee by that Association for the purpose of
training boys and girls to habits of physical purity,
with especial reference to personal chastity and the
non-use, in any form, of alcoholics and narcotics. …
I believe that 'the love of money is the root of all
evil:' that it has warped and minimised more lives,
turned more homes into small compacts of perdition,
and defeated the Gospel's blessed purpose more
ingeniously than all other curses that ever crazed
the human heart."

With a few more brief extracts from that volume
to which we have already been so largely indebted,
we must draw our memoir to a close,—extracts in
which the clear bright mind and sweet spirit of the
writer reflects itself.

"Doubtless, in early days, when the conflict was
between idolatry and the worship of God, 'Divine
service' may have rightly consisted largely in sermon,
song and prayer; but to call that 'service' now, as
is universally done, seems to me a mockery. That
is a delight, a coveted and blessed means of growth;
but 'service' now is to our fellow-men, and he whose
purse and work are not invested there knows nothing
about 'Divine service,' and might well name his place
of Sunday lounging and æsthetics the 'Church of the
Divine Emptiness,' or 'The Church of the Celestial
Sugar Plum.'

"I hold that word 'anxiety' to be strongly
atheistic, and have endeavoured to weed it out of
my vocabulary. 'Careful for nothing, and in everything
a giver of thanks,' is what the commonest
sort of a Christian is sacredly bound to be, or to
become.

"What the world most needs is mothering, and
most of all in the Spirit's natural home, the Church,
and on the Sabbath day.… The sine quâ non of
our success is mutual faith and fellowship. We must
'have fervent charity among ourselves.' It is not
uncharitable to judge an act as good or bad, but we
should be very slow to judge the actor bad.

"'Lord Jesus, receive my spirit,' is the deepest
voice out of my soul. Receive it every instant,
voluntarily given back to Thyself, and receive it in
the hour when I drop this earthly mantle that I wear
to-day, and pass onward to the world invisible, but
doubtless not far off."

Miss Willard did not come again to England after
the autumn of 1896. Her health was failing considerably,
and even the months spent at a sanatorium
in New Castile did not permanently restore her
strength. She, however, attended the W.W.C.T.U.
Convention at Toronto and Buffalo in 1897, declaring
herself, in her ever brave and cheery way, to be "none
the worse for it."

Towards the close of that year she went to New
York for a few weeks, where the proprietor of the
Royal Empire Hotel insisted that she should be his
guest.

Here she was attacked by influenza, on which
ensued dangerous gastric complications. There is
no doubt that her delicate frame had been broken
down by years of overwork, for without any warning
the news was a few days later flashed to her friends
all over the world that Frances Willard was dead.

Mrs. Willard had passed away in 1891 at the
advanced age of eighty-seven, and this last and most
nobly famous of her children followed her on the
17th of February, 1898. A few months later the
mortal remains of the "Uncrowned Queen" were
cremated, in accordance with her repeatedly expressed
wish, and interred in the family grave at Rose Hill
Cemetery.

head.hi:
CHAPTER I.
STRONG, FOR GOOD OR ILL.

div2.p:
Wherever power, which is strength in
action, exists, it must inevitably make itself
known. Wind, water, steam—every force
of Nature, must have an outlet, and the strength of
character with which some children are endowed from
birth shows itself at an early age. This is probably
the origin of the belief that the most troublesome boys
make the finest men.

This, however, is not true, as some fond parents
mistakenly imagine, of the perverse vagaries of the
spoiled child—the tyrant in embryo—but only of the
boys or girls who, teeming with ideas and overflowing
with energy, find it hard to learn self-restraint and
obedience to the wishes of those whose judgment and
experience are more ripe than own.

The eagerness must be curbed, the impetuosity
restrained, the energies directed into right channels,
and many are the conflicts which occur between the
child and the parent, the pupil and the teacher, ay,
and between the higher and lower nature of the subject
himself, ere the victory for right alone is won.

Naturally gentle and "biddable" children, who are
always inclined to wait to be led, either by their elders
or more go-ahead playmates, know nothing of this
warfare, nor of the bitter tears which are shed by the
vanquished or the penitent. They also have their
place in the world—in God's great garden there is
room for the tender creeper as well as the sturdy shrub
—but they will never "make their mark" upon society,
nor powerfully sway, either for good or evil, the
generation into which they are born.

We are not, therefore, surprised to learn that Agnes
Weston as a child was "for some years a source of
great anxiety to her parents;" and that her "strong
will and passionate temper had need of much careful
training."

Happily, both for herself and the thousands to
whom she has been made a blessing, that training was
bestowed upon her.

Miss Weston's father, a barrister, and a man of
much scientific culture, was an earnest and humble
Christian, who delighted to use his knowledge and his
talents to glorify God by showing the wonders of His
infinite skill in the heavens and on earth. It is needless
to say that his daughter was the child of many
prayers, and reared under the inestimable influences
of noble example.

Mrs. Weston, who died in 1895 at the advanced
age of eighty-four years, was always "all that was
loving, true and good."

"Although," adds her daughter, "weak and suffering
in health, she always so forgot her own trials that
she made home the brightest, happiest place in the
world for her children. She won their confidence and
love, and kept it to her latest breath. Singularly gifted,
and endowed with a sweet personal presence, she used
all in her Master's service."

Quite late in life, when many would have excused
themselves from self-denial on account of the infirmities
of old age, Mrs. Weston, under the influence
of an address by Canon Basil Wilberforce, signed the
total abstinence pledge, which she kept unbroken until
the day of her death, nearly twenty years afterwards.

No wonder that Miss Weston herself should exclaim,
"Woe to me, if with such a father and mother, and
with such home influences, I had been aught but a
child of God and a worker in His vineyard! "

Training, however, does but guide; it cannot alter,
much less create, the natural bent of temperament and
disposition. Agnes Weston's vigour and energy, her
love of fighting opposition and surmounting difficulties,
were her birthright.

A friend of her father, a phrenologist, on examining
the exterior signs of the child's cerebral development,
prophesied that her career would be a remarkable one.
He further expressed his conviction that a crisis would
some day occur in her life, when she would "turn
decisively either to the right or left, would choose to
be great either in the service of God or that of the
world."

Those who believe that mental superiority is an
evidence of "good blood" and noble origin, will be
interested to learn that the ancestors of the subject of
this sketch were actually among the aristocratic
Normans who "came over with William the Conqueror;"
the first of the name of whom record exists
being Raoul de Bailleul de Weston, the English-sounding
suffix relating, we presume, to the lands and manors
wherewith the great Norman rewarded his loyal
follower. In any case, it is worth noting that the
family seems to have been distinguished by remarkable
force of character from that remote time until the
present.

Agnes Weston did nothing by halves. She was
always "out and out" either for good or bad.

Up to the age of sixteen, though brought up amid
such eminently Christian surroundings, she was not
merely formal and lifeless in the performance of
religious duties, she absolutely ignored the commonest
means of grace—save that of attendance at Divine
worship, which was doubtless more or less compulsory,—but
Bible-reading and private prayer were
utterly neglected. Not only passively, like so many
people, but actively irreligious did this young girl
appear.

It was by the ministry of the Rev. James, now
Canon, Fleming, that Agnes Weston's conscience first
became awakened. He was appointed to the incumbency
of All Saints' Chapel, Bath, to which town the
Westons, while Agnes was yet an infant, had from
London removed.

Strange that the instinct of combativeness, which
phrenologists tell us is the source of most of the
active good that is accomplished in the world, should
in its crude condition have at once impelled Miss
Weston to violently oppose the working of God's
Holy Spirit! Startling, indeed, is it to read from her
own pen such a confession as this: —

"I was obliged to go to church, but I was determined
not to listen, and oftentimes when the preacher
gave out the text, I have stopped my ears, and shut
my eyes that I might neither see nor hear."

But the Heavenly Father would not give up His
child, the Shepherd would not cease to follow and
patiently call to the lamb that was lost.

The loving parents kept on praying, Mr. Fleming,
little guessing how strong, yet rebellious a soul was
struggling against his home-thrusts, continued to
preach God's truth, a good Christian friend helped
in the work, and presently the armour of obstinate
repugnance began to yield.

Agnes was persuaded to read the Bible for herself
and to think about it.

For hours, then, we are told, she used to wander
about the fields, Bible in hand, and many a night she
was sleepless from agony of soul.

It really seems as though Satan, foreseeing the
incalculable injury to his work that would ensue if
once he let this vigorous character, this large heart and
busy mind, escape into the ranks of the Saviour's
host, put forth all his efforts to entangle and discourage
her, raging to hold her back.

He bewildered her with doubts, he tortured her
with the paralysing suggestions of scepticism, he
terrified her by pointing to a broken law. He used
every art "acquired," as we once heard a preacher
remark, "in his 6000 years of experience" in deceiving
humanity, to baffle her in her search for light and
peace. She was worth fighting for!

But the Victor over all was too strong for him;
Agnes had at last yielded herself to the guidance of
the Holy Spirit, so soon or late, all must be well with
her. Yet the conflict was drear and long.

It was during this time of inward unrest that she
commenced, with her usual irresistible energy, the
mastery of the organ, preferring, characteristically, that
instrument to any other, because of the difficulty of
manipulating it.

For some time she studied under the late J. R. Pyne,
Esq., organist of the Abbey Church, Bath; wrestling
with technicalities and practising with a perseverance
that was only checked by the endurance of the organ-blower,
whose strength was often unequal to the
industry of the student.

At the recommendation of Mr. Pyne, who thought
highly of his pupil's ability, Miss Weston was enabled
to place herself after a while under the tuition of that
celebrated organist and composer, Dr. S. S. Wesley,
of Gloucester Cathedral; and for a time she might be
found every day, and nearly all day, seated at the
cathedral organ, preparing herself unconsciously for
the work in after life which was being prepared for her.

It is to this period that an incident pertains which
well illustrates Miss Weston's courage and resolution.

Dr. Wesley was one evening giving her a lesson in
the cathedral after dark; no lights were allowed
except in the organ-loft, the remainder of the vast,
echoing building being engulfed in darkness.

Dr. Wesley was summoned away in haste by a
messenger from home soon after the lesson began, but
he promised to speedily return. He was compelled,
however, to lock the young lady alone in the cathedral
during his absence, as it was against rule to leave the
doors open. But to this she did not in the least object.

Dr. Wesley had not been gone long, before even
Miss Weston's absorption in her occupation was disturbed
by the sound, real or imagined, of footsteps on
the stones of the aisle below. Slowly but surely they
drew nearer, and to the performer's horror, paused in
the side chapel at the foot of the organ loft! She
knew it was not her tutor's familiar tread, and the
stories of the ghost of a certain Crusader, by which
the dim, mysterious pile was said to be haunted, came
rushing into her mind.

But Agnes Weston was not one to sit still and
tremble; she must up and do! She sprang to
her feet, threw aside the curtain and saw—nothing!

The strange sounds, she concluded, were occasioned
probably by the wind sobbing around the pillars and
tombs in the cloisters and aisle; and reassured she
went quietly on with her practising until Dr. Wesley
appeared.

True foreshadowing of the pluck and determination
with which in after years she would face obstacles, both
tangible and visionary, and by which many a dark
spectre of ignorance, godlessness and intemperance
should be put to the rout.

head.hi:
CHAPTER II.
TEMPERANCE AND THE BLUE-JACKETS.

div2.p:
It was not until after nearly ten years of struggle
and strife that Agnes Weston found her "desired
haven" of rest and peace in Jesus Christ.

The hushing of the storm was so gradual, the return
of the tempest for a long time so recurrent, that the
exact date when calm commenced its final reign
cannot be definitely given; but by the year 1868 we
find Miss Weston actively and happily engaged in
various forms of Christian work, teaching the young,
visiting the sick, and ministering to the dying.

We are quite prepared to hear that in the Sunday
school her force of character and love of difficulty
brought every unruly class in turn beneath her firm
but kindly hand, and that "the more unmanageable
they were, the more she delighted in, as the curate
expressed it, 'licking them into shape.'"

Of course, she loved big boys! The future
"mother" of Jack Tar could not do otherwise. And
by degrees her class of senior lads developed into a
class for working-men, and this in turn was the
nucleus of her mission work at Walcot, near Bath,
where Working-Men's Bible-Classes and Prayer-meetings,
Temperance and Band of Hope efforts
were crowned with much blessing.

For Miss Weston was a staunch advocate of
Temperance even before she had herself signed the
pledge. The story of how it came about that she
was induced to make that decisive stand has often
been related, but it is so good, and carries so striking
a lesson to other Christian workers, as to be worth
telling again.

At the close of one of her Temperance meetings,
a notorious drunkard came up to the table and wished
to sign the pledge.

Miss Weston was delighted, but her triumph was
soon checked, for as the man held the pen in his
hand, before he began to write, he suddenly looked
up at her and asked:—
"If you please, Miss Weston, be you a teetotaller?"

Somewhat taken aback by this unexpected query,
Miss Weston replied, "I only take a glass of wine
occasionally, and in strict moderation."

The man at once laid down the pen, saying that
he would do the same, and take a glass sometimes
"in moderation."

Needless to say, this was to him impossible, and
he soon plunged back into his old ways.

"That night," adds Miss Weston, "I saw my duty
very plainly, and I enrolled my name in the pledge-book,
heartily wishing that I had done so before."

The assembling of the Somerset Militia every year
at Bath, for training, was the cause of Miss Weston
becoming interested in soldiers,—for the time of the
sailors, though approaching, had not yet fully come.

When coffee and reading-rooms were started for
the benefit of the men, she naturally took great
interest in them, and frequently assisted at the
meetings which were arranged for recreation. She
also undertook a Sunday Bible-class, and the result
of her efforts became so apparent in the improved
behaviour of the men, that as one officer testified,
they were "not like the same fellows."

From Tommy Atkins it is but a step to his
brother, Jack Tar, and this is how, in Miss Weston's
case, that step was taken.

In that same eventful year, 1868, she wrote a
friendly letter to a soldier of her acquaintance who
was on his way to India. The man, proud and
pleased, showed the letter to one of the seamen,
a sick-berth steward, evoking the longing comment,
"I would give anything if I could get a letter like
that sometimes! Do you think that lady would
write to me?"

"I am sure she would. I will write and ask her,"
replied the other.

He did so. Miss Weston gladly answered it,
complying with his request. And that letter to one
friendless seaman, yearning for sympathy, on board
the Crocodile, was the germ of her present stupendous
and world-wide labour among sailors.

For the next thing was that the grateful fellow
wrote to her himself, enclosing the names of several
other sailors who would be as thankful for a letter
as he was. She penned kindly, encouraging epistles
to them all, and week by week her correspondence
steadily increased.

At last the requests for these much-prized letters
became so numerous that it was impossible to keep
pace with them except by the regular supplementary
issue of a printed one. Thus Miss Weston's invaluable
"Monthly Letter" to Seamen, Marines, and
Marine Artillery was started, and it proved from the
outset an immense success. From a circulation of
1500 copies per month in 1872, it rose to its present
astounding figure of 21,000! And in addition, Miss
Weston and her three Secretaries write to thousands
of men individually.

The pleasure which these "Letters" give to lonely
sailors all over the world, their significance to those
ofttimes monotonous and isolated lives, and the
spiritual blessing which in innumerable cases has
followed their perusal, it is impossible to estimate.

The issue of a letter specially addressed to boys
soon became necessary, for they too clamoured
for a share in the treat. This was commenced in 1874,
and the circulation soon reached many thousands
per month

Miss Weston's warm heart had not long been
opened to receive Jack Tar, before she became deeply
impressed with the fact that his worst foe is drink.

Having herself, ever since that memorable night
at the Walcot Mission Room, been an out-and-out
total abstainer, she was anxious to bring the power of
her persuasions to bear upon the sailor.

This was by no means, at first, so easy as might be
supposed, the discipline and rules of the Service being
somewhat inflexible. But Admiral Sir W. King Hall,
K.C.B., proved her earliest and most influential friend.
He had heard her give a short address to the
Devonport dockyard men in their dinner hour, and
willingly recommended her to the captains of all the
ships in the harbour. One after another of them she
was thus permitted to visit, pledge-book in hand, and
her earnest, affectionate words were not without effect
upon the men.

A very amusing episode is related in connection
with this phase of Miss Weston's work. We will
describe it in her own graphic words:—

"I found myself one day on board H.M.S. Topaze,
of course by the kind permission of the commander.
He was most interested in the proceedings, and was
present himself; the crowd of blue-jackets were
grouped before me on the lower deck. After addressing
them, anxious not to lose an opportunity of taking
the names of those who wished to enrol themselves on
the Topaze's books, I asked permission to do so, which
was freely granted; but the difficulty still to be solved
was the want of a table. I looked around, and seeing,
as I supposed, a bread-tub with its bright polished
bands standing near, I asked if I might be allowed to
use it as a table.

"' Certainly,' was the answer, with a smile; 'but it's
the first time it has been put to such a use. Now,
men, a couple of hands to roll out the grog-tub!'

"Amid cheers and laughter the grog-tub was rolled
out, and a capital table it made, on which more than
sixty enrolled their names. One young sailor came
forward and signed his name; after doing so he laid
down the pen, and, significantly rapping the tub with
his knuckles, said, 'There goes a nail in your coffin,
old fellow!'

"After all that wished to do so had entered their
names, the commander took up the book, and running
his eye down the lists, significantly added, 'Sixty odd
nails to-day; if they all hold firm I won't give much
for the old grog-tub's life.'"

Years have passed by since that first nail was
driven home, and if the grog-tub has not yet been
tossed overboard altogether, its power over the fine
fellows in our Navy has lessened to an astonishing
degree. Every ship in the Service has now a branch
of the Royal Naval Temperance Society in full swing
on board. During a recent year 6021 pledges were
taken at Devonport and Portsmouth alone.

As an encouragement to faithfulness, medals are
offered to those who keep the pledge unbroken for five
years, with "bars" for ten, fifteen and twenty years
abstinence. Stars of merit are also given to the Committee
of any ship showing ten per cent. Of the ship's
company on the books of the society for three months.
Upwards of 1500 of these medals and stars have
already been won.

Voluntary tributes to the vastly improved character
of our blue-jackets are often given by officers and
others who are in a position to compare the present
with the past.

A gentleman who chanced to be in Lisbon during
a recent visit of H.M.S. Australia, and whose duties
as a civilian have afforded him opportunities of witnessing
the behaviour for twenty years past of British
crews in many parts of the world, has testified that,
"I must say I never saw a crew behave as well as the
men of the Australia. They were perfect gentlemen,
and were a credit to their officers and their country."

The Times' correspondent at Lisbon also wrote of
the "quiet, dignified behaviour" of the men while on
shore as exciting "universal admiration."

No wonder that Miss Weston and her zealous
helpers feel their hearts glow with gratitude to God
and pride in their men, as they read such eulogies as
these! It is abundantly evident that their work has
not been in vain.

In the pleasant town of Devonport, exactly opposite
the gates of the Royal Dockyard, stands a handsome
pile of buildings, known as the Royal Sailors'
Rest. It occupies the site formerly filled by three
public-houses.

The exterior of this Jack Tar's hotel is most enticing;
plenty of glittering mirrors, gas and gilding,
while the white and gold china barrels with silver taps
bearing the inscriptions, "New Milk," "Lemonade,"
"Ginger-Beer," etc., vie with the shining coffee urns
in aspiring to quench the thirst of Jack when
ashore.

Plenty of good food, hot, sweet, and above all in big
platefuls, is also to be had at a reasonable price, while
a large smoking-room adjoins.

Upstairs is a comfortably furnished reading and
