last consulted a medical man, and submitted to an
examination.

Soon she knew that the fiat had gone forth—expected,
through some strange presentiment, for more
than a year past, though not in the guise in which it
actually came—"Thou shalt die, and not live."

Impelled by some motive which no one has been
able quite to understand, Sister Dora extorted from
this doctor a pledge of inviolable secrecy, and went on
with her work just the same as usual.

Cancer, the dread disease which had claimed her for
its victim, is of slow development. All through the
year 1877 it preyed upon this Spartan woman unsuspected
by the dearest friend, or those who worked with
her night and day. Bright, merry, capable as ever,
the only difference which might have struck those who
knew her was that a little pony-carriage which had
been presented to her as a tribute of gratitude some
time before, was used more than formerly for driving
to see patients who could not be received into the
hospital.

In January, 1878, she wrote in acknowledgment of
a letter received on her last birthday:—"I could go on
writing until my ideas all ran to ink, and there would
be none left.… It was a glad day to me. The world
seemed so full of warm, loving hearts. Such lots of
nice letters and remembrances; and then, I am so
sure of the Loving Heart above, and being another
year nearer Home."

To a perplexed young friend she wisely wrote:
"No one thing in itself is much better than another,
and no one can better themselves in any case by stepping
out of the place in which the Master puts them."

In the month of June, 1878, Sister Dora went away
for a fortnight's holiday, and almost immediately on
her return an outbreak of typhoid fever necessitated
the closing of the temporary hospital, and again
released her from the work which she was destined
never to resume. Then, the first use she made of her
liberty was to gather together as many of her old
patients as she could, with night nurses and servants
connected with the hospital, and treat them all to a
day's outing at Lichfield.

In the light of our knowledge that she had entered
upon the last half-year of her life, it is almost incredible
to read that "she was in unusually high
spirits, talking and laughing with them in the train,
and actually jumping out to gather some flowers
which grew on the railway banks while the train
stopped unexpectedly."

A little later she went to join some of her nieces in
the Isle of Man, and on this occasion not only enjoyed
sea-bathing herself, but took the opportunity of teaching
her nieces to swim.

In the autumn she went to Paris, to see the Exhibition,
and was delighted with all she saw. But about
the end of September came a sudden collapse. She
was in London at the time, and at once hurried to
Birmingham to consult the doctor who shared her
terrible secret. Here she became so very ill, that it
was feared she could not be removed to Walsall alive.
Early in October, however, the journey was accomplished.

For the next three months Sister Dora's sufferings
were agonising. Once she wrote, "I have not had
two hours' sleep for four days and nights, but in the
midst of the fiery furnace there was a form like unto
the Son of God."

Soon, however, writing became impossible, and she
could only dictate letters to her friends, who were still
kept in ignorance of the true nature of her complaint,
and the disease being complicated with lung trouble
which caused a racking cough, everybody believed
that she was dying of consumption.

On the 4th of November, the new hospital was
declared by the Mayor to be open "in the name of
Sister Dora." It was a pathetic ceremony, for it
was then known to all that in spite of lingering
hopes, their "dear lady's" bright face would never
smile among them again.

It was hard to realise, for she still rallied again
and again, her marvellous constitution resisting the
inroads of disease. On her better days, she would
receive many visitors, and laugh and joke with them
as of old, until the thought of death in connection
with that irrepressible spirit appeared impossible.
But there were other times when the horror of the
approaching struggle seemed almost to overwhelm
her. She believed it probable that the end would
come during one of her severe fits of coughing, and
the idea was terrible to her. Nevertheless, one of
her nurses, who had watched many death-beds,
testified, "I never saw such faith and patience."

During the week before Christmas, she repeatedly
said, "I hope I shall sing my Christmas Carol in
heaven!" But release had been so long-expected
and delayed that as the days passed on it seemed
unlikely that her desire would be granted.

But Heaven was merciful, and the last earthly
wish of this prayerful soul who had won so many
boons for others was not to be refused. On the
afternoon of the 24th of December, the spirit of
Sister Dora passed peacefully and painlessly away.

The funeral, by her own special request, was as
plain as possible, but it was attended by grief-stricken
mourners in throngs, from almost every
rank in society, bishops and town magnates, rough
men and ragged women, testifying alike, with tearful
eyes, to the sincerity of their sorrow.

Various memorials have been raised by the people
of Walsall in honour of her whom they love to call
"Our sister Dora." £700 were collected for the
Convalescent Home which was the object nearest
to her heart at the time of her death; a life-like
portrait of her was painted for the Board-Room of
the Hospital; and a magnificent stained-glass window,
costing about £300, was placed in the parish church.

But the grandest and most conspicuous of all is
the beautiful statue of Sister Dora, which occupies
a central position in the town; this, with its pedestal
and relievo representing her attending to the sufferers
from the Burchills Explosion, cost £1050, a great
part of which was contributed in small sums by the
working-men, who preferred a white marble statue to
any other form of memorial. It was unveiled in the
autumn of 1886, in the presence of about 40,000
spectators.

Commenting on this event, the Standard summed
up the character of Sister Dora as "a warm-hearted,
tender, unaffected woman, who was loved—as Charles
Lamb was said to love his friends—not in spite of
her faults, but was loved, faults and all."

When some future historian takes up his pen
to describe the social progress of England
during the latter half of the nineteenth
century, there will be one family, neither rich, titled,
nor politically conspicuous, whose work and influence
it will be impossible to ignore.

The world has probably never seen a more remarkable
group of men and women, bound together by
the closest ties of both sympathy and blood, than
those bearing the now universally famous name of
Booth, nor one whose spiritual power over their own
generation has been so far-reaching and deep.

From Arctic snows to the burning sands of Africa,
from inventive America to quaint Japan, the Salvation
Army has become a household word, and the "Mother
of the Army" was Catherine Booth.

Born at Ashbourne, in Derbyshire, in January,
1829, when the reactionary fervour and strictness
of Methodism was still thrilling a slumbering Church,
Kate Mumford was reared in a family where both
elements appear to have been exemplified in a marked
degree. Her father, John Mumford, was a lay
preacher belonging to the Wesleyan body, while
her mother, a woman of great strength of character
united to religious earnestness, though brought up
in the Church of England, had been converted, before
her marriage, under the influence of a Methodist
mission.

Little Catherine, a striking-looking girl, with flashing
black eyes and curly hair, was the only daughter
in a family of five, and of her brothers, the youngest
alone survived his infancy; her position, therefore,
was almost like that of an only child.

Mrs. Mumford held very decided views on the
subject of the training of children, and so convinced
was she of the prevalence of parental neglect and the
dangers of bad companionship, that she did not
permit her little girl and boy to mix with any playmates
of their own age; nor did Catherine even attend
school until she was twelve years old.

Mrs. Mumford, however, did her best to make
up for this deprivation by being herself her little
daughter's constant companion and confidante, and
it is very possible that to a child of Catherine's
delicate physique and precociously thoughtful mind,
this comradeship was even more congenial than that
of average juveniles would have been.

But although romping games and fascinating storybooks
were alike denied to little Kate, she was not
wholly without the natural joys of childhood, for it is
recorded that she possessed a family of dolls to which
she was devotedly attached. As is usual with
children, Kate's play was both a faithful reflection of
her surroundings and a forecast of her future life.
Not only did she wash, feed, and industriously sew
for her wax and wooden babies, but we are told that
she would even pray with them, in the earnestness of
her maternal zeal!

It is needless to say that Mrs. Mumford's daughter
was early taught to read and love her Bible, and before
she was twelve years old she had read entirely through
the sacred book eight times, thus early acquiring that
familiarity with Scripture which was to be of such
service to the world in years to come.

Although trained, in some respects, with so much
strictness, it would not appear that the little girl
was unduly repressed. She was allowed to join in
the conversation of her parents at an early age, and
even when visitors were present. "By the time
I was twelve," she says, "I had my own ideas in
politics, and could fight my father across the table.
Among other matters discussed was the Catholic
Emancipation Bill. My father was in favour of it,
while I was very much opposed to it, arguing that the
way in which the Catholics had invariably misused
political power proved that they were unfit to be intrusted
with it."

Catherine's sympathies were always with the poor
and wretched, and being by moral constitution as
high-spirited and brave as she was fragile in body, she
never lacked the courage to act up to her convictions.
A striking incident of early life will prove this.

While bowling her hoop in the street one day, she
saw a drunken man being dragged to the police-station
by a constable, and followed by a jeering,
hooting crowd. Instantly a sense of profound pity
for the unfortunate culprit overmastered the horror
which a gently nurtured little girl must naturally have
felt, and springing to the man's side, Kate walked
with him to the lock-up; a true foreshadowing of the
courage and tenderness which in time to come was to
make Mrs. Booth the friend and champion of the outcast
all the world over.

Equally brave was she in defence of the dumb creation,
and many an over-driven horse or goaded sheep
would have blessed the name of one who not only
pitied its sufferings but had the courage to interfere on
its behalf, had it but possessed the tongue to speak.

In after years she frequently took clandestine
supplies of food to poor, under-fed animals which she
noticed in the fields, and many a threepenny or sixpenny
bit did she bestow upon seaside donkey-boys
along with bright, kindly exhortations to be good to
the animals in their care.

It is not surprising to learn that Kate Mumford was
one of those children who take real pleasure in attendance
at religious services, nor that she was deeply and
practically interested in the progress of missions to
the heathen. She voluntarily denied herself, and was
also indefatigable in begging for money from others
in order to help in sending the Gospel abroad.

Another philanthropic movement which aroused
the enthusiasm of this remarkable child was that for
the promotion of total abstinence. Before she had
reached her teens we find her writing impassioned
letters to the magazines for which her father subscribed,
concealing her identity beneath a nom de
plume, and even getting the manuscripts copied out by
a friend that the editors might not be prejudiced by
guessing the extreme youth of the writer. Whether
any of these early effusions ever appeared in print,
we are not told.

In the year 1834, the Mumfords removed to Boston
in Lincolnshire, and amongst the members of the
chapel there was a lady, of great devotion and ability,
who was principal of a girls' school. So great was the
friendship and esteem which Mrs. Mumford conceived
for this lady, that in 1841 she arranged, prejudiced as
she had previously been to any but home education,
for Catherine to attend her seminary.

During the girl's two years of school life, she won
the greatest affection and regard from her teacher,
though even her unselfish dislike to surpass or
humiliate others by her superior gifts did not wholly
relieve her from the consequences of youthful jealousy.
Possibly her long isolation from other children had
somewhat unfitted her for their teasing and tricks, for
we hear now of occasional violent outbursts of temper,
for which, however, Kate was always deeply sorry
when the irritation had passed away.

History and geography were her favourite studies,
especially the former, and the way in which she would
analyse and compare the characters brought before
her, inquiring into their motives, and meditating on
the use they made of their power, whether for selfish
aggrandisement or the benefit of the poor, is another
indication of the strong and early bent of her mind
towards practical philanthropy.

Arithmetic she did not like, but in composition she
excelled. We hear nothing about music, and French
was a tabooed accomplishment on account of Mrs.
Mumford's extreme fear that it might lead to the
perusal of pernicious literature in that language. In
after years, however, Catherine considered that in this
particular her mother had made a mistake.

Kate's school days were of comparatively short
duration. When she was fourteen years old they
were brought to a premature close by an attack of
spinal weakness, which compelled her to spend most
of her time lying upon a couch.

It was at this period that, turning from the usual
studies of girls of her age, Catherine devoted her
enforced leisure to reading books dealing with Church
history and theology. Wesley, Finney, Fletcher,
Mosheim, and Neander followed closely on her favourite
"Butler's Analogy" and "Pilgrim's Progress."
She also carefully perused "Newton on Prophecy,"
coming to the conclusion with respect to the latter
that she could better please God by preparing people
for Christ's coming than by endeavouring to fix the
date when it was to take place.

Miss Mumford seems to have been in every respect
more early developed than the average girl, for she
was only fifteen when there devolved upon her the
serious responsibility of accepting or rejecting a
would-be lover!

This young man, who was her cousin, was not
without attractions, but his obviously worldly and
irreligious character finally decided her to break off
all correspondence with him, a step which she never
afterwards had cause to regret.

In1844 the Mumfords removed to London, and
at length took up their residence at Brixton;
here, not many months after her arrival, occurred
what we may assuredly call the most important event
of Catherine's life, namely, her conversion.

In accordance with the views of the religious body
among whom she had been nurtured, the girl felt that
some definite inward convulsion invariably accompanied
true change of heart, and this she was not
aware as yet of having experienced. Therefore, although,
as she says, "I was conscious of having given
myself up fully to God from my earliest years, and
although I was anxious to serve Him and often
realised deep enjoyment in prayer, nevertheless, I
had not the positive assurance that my sins were
forgiven."

The poor child, struggling for peace, passed through
weeks of mental agony, often pacing her room until
two o'clock in the morning, and when, utterly exhausted,
she at length lay down to sleep, she would
place her Bible and hymn-book under her pillow,
praying that she might wake up with the assurance
of salvation.

At length, one morning, when she opened her
hymn-book, her eyes fell upon the words:—
"My God, I am Thine!
What a comfort Divine,—
What a blessing to know that my Jesus is mine."

Instantly, familiar as the lines had been before,
they seemed invested with a new meaning; the long-sought
"assurance of salvation" rushed in upon her
soul like a flood, and, overwhelmed with joy, Catherine
jumped out of bed and at once ran into her mother's
room to tell the good news to her.

It was no doubt a remembrance of this episode
which led Mrs. Booth in after years to insist so
strongly on the possibility of immediate acceptance
and instant salvation and joy, which was so marked a
feature of her own ministrations to inquiring souls.

"For the next six months," she wrote, "I was so
happy that I felt as if I were walking on air. I used
to tremble, and even long to die, lest I should backslide,
or lose the consciousness of God's smile and
favour."

Catherine now joined the Wesleyan Church at
Brixton; but although the Society had in London
at that time some of its most able and eloquent
preachers—the eminent Luke Tyerman being one of
them—the young convert and her mother were not
satisfied, because the services were unaccompanied by
those unmistakable outward manifestations of repentance
and salvation which they deemed essential
proofs of the work of the Holy Spirit.

Of course Catherine's next step was to begin
attending a class-meeting, much more stringently
required of members of the Wesleyan body fifty years
ago than now, and looked upon, indeed, as a sine quâ
non of the Christian life. This class she continued to
attend for the next five years. Here she received
her most valuable training in the art of speaking in
public. For, whatever opinion we may entertain as
to the desirability of forcing a young girl to pray
aloud, and even keeping the rest of the class upon
their knees for five minutes waiting for her to begin,
when she was in such delicate health that the excitement
and exertion were making her ill, there is no
doubt that to this rigorous discipline was owing much
of Mrs. Booth's fluency and power in after life.

But although this experience was no hindrance to
the young enthusiast, the fact that her class-leader's
daughter was allowed to dress in accordance with the
fashions of the world and become engaged to an
unconverted young man, caused her the utmost sorrow
and concern; for she feared that while such inconsistencies
were tolerated, little permanent good could
be accomplished among members of the class.

Like many thoughtful Christians in the leisured
days gone by, Catherine Mumford found pleasure in
recording her religious symptoms and advancement.
Thus in her eighteenth and nineteenth years we find
such occasional entries in her diary as the following,
written at Brighton, where she was staying for the
benefit of her health:—

"14th May, 1847.—This morning, while reading
Rowe's 'Devout Exercises of the Heart,' I was much
blessed, and enabled to give myself afresh into the
hands of God, to do or to suffer all His will. Oh,
that I may be made useful in this family! Lord,
they know Thee not, neither do they seek Thee!
Have mercy upon them, and help me to set an example,
at all times and in all places, worthy of imitation.
Help me to adorn the Gospel of God, my
Saviour, in all things.

"I find much need of watchfulness and prayer, and
have this day taken up my cross in reproving sin.
Lord, follow with the conviction of Thy Spirit all I
have said."

And again, on 28th November, she writes:—"This
has been an especially good day to my soul. … My
desires after holiness have been much increased. This
day I have sometimes seemed on the verge of the
good land. Oh, for mighty faith! I believe the
Lord is willing and able to save me to the uttermost.
I believe the blood of Jesus Christ cleanses from all
sin. And yet there seems something in the way to
prevent me from fully entering in. But to-day I
believe at times I have had tastes of perfect love.
Oh, that these may be droppings before an overwhelming
shower of grace! My chief desire is holiness
of heart. This is the prevailing cry of my soul."

At the beginning of the New Year (1848), she has
the following entry:—

"I have been writing a few daily rules for the
coming year, which I hope will prove a blessing to me
by the grace of God. … I have read my Bible
through twice during the last sixteen months, but I
must read it with more prayer for light and understanding.
Oh, may it be my meat and drink! May
I meditate on it day and night! and then I shall bring
forth fruit in season, my leaf also shall not wither, and
whatsoever I do shall prosper!"

A few days later we have a record which, considering
that shortly before the writer had owned to
feeling "very poorly, and excessively low," does more
credit to her zeal than her discretion:—

"I have renewed my practice of abstaining from
dinner on a Friday, and from butter in the morning.
… Oh, my Lord, help me to be more fully decided
in all things, and not to confer with flesh and blood,
but be bold to take up and firm to sustain the consecrated
cross."

It was about this time that a great agitation arose
in the Wesleyan community, leading ultimately to
the withdrawal or expulsion of about one hundred
thousand of its members.

Briefly, the autocratic government of the hundred
ministers, who in accordance with John Wesley's Deed
Poll formed the Conference, aroused feelings of rebellion
in the minds of certain of their brethren who were
not thus in office. Anonymous pamphlets were published,
purporting to expose serious errors in the
administration. These naturally gave great offence
to the Conference, who endeavoured to fix upon the
masked offenders, with the result that three ministers
were expelled from the society, and a number of others
severely reprimanded.

The numbers of malcontents, however, were increased
rather than diminished by those stringent
measures, and in a short time they had formed themselves
into a body, subsequently known as the
Reformers, and thousands of their sympathisers were
virtually excommunicated by the Conference.

Miss Mumford was ever inclined to be on the side
of the people, and those who seemed to be oppressed.
Possessing from her earliest years, as we have seen,
the courage of her convictions, she so boldly expressed
her opinions on this subject as to draw upon herself
the censure of her conservative-minded class-leader,
who finding her firm in her sympathy with those whom
she believed to be in the right, reluctantly decided to
withhold her ticket of membership. In other words,
Catherine Mumford was expelled from the Wesleyan
Church.

The Reformers had by this time commenced to
hold meetings in the neighbourhood of Catherine's
home, and when she was offered by them the senior
class in their Sunday School, she willingly accepted
the post, and threw herself into the work with all her
heart.

"I used to have some wonderful times with my
class," she tells us. "I made them pray, and I am
sure that anybody coming into one of those meetings
would have seen very much what a Salvation Army
consecration meeting is now. They usually all
stopped, and sometimes our prayer-meetings would
last an hour and a half. Often went on till I lost
my voice, not regaining it for a day or two after.
I used to invite them to talk to me privately, if anything
I said had struck them, and at such times they
would pour out their hearts to me as if I had been
their mother.

"However, I was a good deal disappointed with the
Reformers. I had hoped that we were upon the eve
of a great spiritual revival. Instead of this, everything
was conducted very much in the ordinary style,
and I soon became heartily sick of the spirit of debate
and controversy which prevailed to such a degree as
to cripple the life and power of the concern."

head.hi:
CHAPTER III
COURTSHIP, MARRIAGE, AND MATERNITY.

div2.p:
It was in the autumn of 1851 that amongst the
local preachers chosen to fill in turn the pulpit of
the Reformers' Chapel which Miss Mumford and her
mother now attended, occurred the name of a certain
Mr. William Booth.

This young man, who, reared in the Church of
England, had received his first definite religious impressions
at a Wesleyan Chapel, had from boyhood
been in the habit of holding cottage meetings and
visiting the sick and dying. He also delighted in
assisting at open-air services, the object of which was
to draw the unthinking to attendance at Divine
worship.

Mr. Booth's great desire was to be a preacher, and
he offered himself for that purpose to the Wesleyan
Connexion, but was rather coldly received.

He then devoted his overflowing energies to open-air
work in the streets and greens of Kennington, but
although he had. so far, held himself aloof from the
Reformers, he became suspected by the minister in
charge of his circuit with bring tainted with their
heresy, and, like Catherine Mumford, but with less
justification, he too was summarily expelled.

As soon, however, as the Reformers heard of this,
they cordially invited him to join their ranks; he
acceded to their request, and thus found himself in
the pulpit of Binfield House Chapel.

Miss Mumford was present on the occasion that he
preached, and was very much impressed with both
Mr. Booth and his sermon.

Asked her opinion of the latter a few days later by
Mr. Rabbits, one of the leading men connected with
the chapel, she replied that she considered it the best
sermon she had yet heard at Binfield Hall.

Shortly afterwards Mr. Rabbits invited the principal
Reformers of that district to tea at his house, and
social intercourse. Mrs. and Miss Mumford were
among the guests, and also William Booth.

The latter, who was a clever elocutionist, was
pressed, in the course of the evening, to give a striking
temperance recitation, entitled "The Grog Seller's
Dream." This in its turn gave rise to conversation
on the subject of Total Abstinence, drawing from
Miss Mumford some convincing expressions of her
own strong views in favour of the movement, and
revealing the fact that on some important points she
and the young preacher were wholly in sympathy.

Early in 1852, William Booth relinquished business
and gave himself up wholly to the work of the
ministry. The Reformers had appointed him their
pastor, and he commenced his labours on a salary of
fifty pounds a-year.

The acquaintance between him and Catherine
Mumford soon developed into friendship, which ere
long ripened into a warmer feeling on both sides.
But realising that his position and income were
Somewhat insecure, Mr. Booth shrank for some time
from asking the young lady to enter into a definite
engagement.

Catherine, on her part, behaved as unselfishly and
disinterestedly as did her lover, begging him only to
make sure that every step he took was in accordance
with the will of God.

But in May of that year both were eventually
brought to see that it would be with the blessing of
God and for the furtherance of His work that two
Whose deepest longings and dearest aims were identical,
should become one; and the betrothal was
sealed.

The love-letters that were subsequently exchanged
between this remarkable couple are as far removed
from earthliness—those of the young lady especially
so—as were the minds and aspirations of the writers.

Not many recently-engaged girls, we venture to
think, would write to her beloved in such a strain as
this:—

"My dear William,—I ought to be happy after
enjoying your company all the evening, but now
you are gone and I am alone, I feel a regret consonant
with the height of my enjoyment. How wide the
difference between heavenly and earthly joys! The
former satiate the soul and reproduce themselves.
The latter, after planting in our soul the seeds of
future griefs and cares, take their flight and leave an
aching void.

"How wisely God has apportioned our cup! He
does not give us all sweetness, lest we should rest
satisfied with earth; nor all bitterness, lest we grow
weary and disgusted with our lot. But He wisely
mixes the two, so that if we drink the one, we must also
taste the other. And perhaps a time is coming when
we shall see that the proportions of this cup of human
joy and sorrow are more equally adjusted than we
now imagine—that souls capable of enjoyments above
the vulgar crowd can also feel sorrow, in comparison
with which theirs is but like the passing April cloud
in contrast with the long Egyptian night.

"How wise an ordination this is we cannot now
discover. It will require the light which streams from
the Eternal Throne to reveal to us the blessed effects
of having the sentence of death written on all our
earthly enjoyments. I often anticipate the glorious
employment of investigating the mysterious workings
of Divine Providence. Oh, may it be our happy lot
to assist each other in these heavenly researches in
that pure, bright world above!"

After this, it is almost refreshing to find one record
of natural girlishness. In later life Mrs. Booth confessed
that "I had, like most people, certain preferences.
The first was that the object of my choice
should be a minister.… Then I very much desired
that he should be dark and tall, and had a special
liking for the name of 'William.' Singularly enough,
in adhering to my essentials, my fancies were also
gratified, and in my case the promise was certainly
fulfilled, 'Delight thyself in the Lord, and He shall
give thee the desires of thy heart.'"

Mrs. Booth's views on the subject of courtship and
marriage, formulated when the force of her strong
character in its maturity had burst the bonds of that
stilted religiosity of language which, to some minds,
may mar the compositions of her early years, are so
wise and practical that they may well be quoted
here; would that we had space to give her words
in full.

"Who can wonder," she remarks, "that marriage
is so often a failure, when we observe the ridiculous
way in which courtship is commonly carried on?…

"Perhaps the greatest evil of all is hurry. Young
people do not give themselves time to know each
other before an engagement is formed. They should
take time and make opportunities for acquainting
themselves with each other's character, disposition,
and peculiarities before coming to a decision.…

"As quite a young girl I early made up my mind
to certain qualifications which I regarded as indispensable
to the forming of any engagement.

"In the first place I was determined that his
religious views must coincide with mine. He must
be a sincere Christian, not a nominal one, or a mere
Church member, but truly converted to God.…
Thousands of Christians, women especially, have
proved by bitter experience that neither money,
position, nor any other worldly advantage has availed
to prevent the punishment that invariably attends
disobedience to the command, 'Be not unequally
yoked together with unbelievers.'

"The second essential that I resolved upon was that
he should be a man of sense. I knew that I could
never respect a fool, or one much weaker mentally
than myself. … There ought to be similarity or
congeniality of character as well as of grace.…

"The third essential consisted of oneness of views
and tastes, any idea of lordship or ownership being
lost in love. … Of course, there must and will be
it is a pleasure and a joy to yield our own wills to
those for whom we have real affection, whenever it
can be done with an approving conscience. …

"Another resolution I made was that I would
never marry a man who was not a total abstainer,
and this from conviction, and not merely in order
to gratify me."

Having, therefore, been so happy as to find her
every requirement fulfilled in the man who loved
her, Catherine Mumford, on the 16th of June, 1855,
became Mrs. William Booth.

Her bridegroom, who for some months previously
had been conducting evangelistic services in various
parts of the country with marked success, was now
appointed by the Annual Conference of the New
Connexion to the permanent work of itinerant
missions, or "revivals," as they were formerly called.

It was a keen disappointment to both that
Catherine's health, always delicate, forbade her at
first to accompany Mr. Booth on these journeys, and
the letters which passed between them while separated
were of a tenderly affectionate tone. Very soon,
however, she was able to join him, and an extract
or two from a letter she wrote to him during a brief
absence shortly after, indicates that her nature was
already expanding in the sunshine of love and joy,
and coming out of its chrysalis bondage like a butterfly
in spring.

"Here I sit under a hedge in the beautiful lane
you pointed out to me. It is one of the loveliest days
old earth has ever basked in.… All Nature seems
to be exulting in existence, and your moralising little
wife is much better in health and in a mood to enjoy
all these beauties and advantages to the utmost. …
I feel perfectly at home here, and experience just
that free, sweet, wholesome kind of atmosphere which
I have so long been panting for. My natural spirits
are in a high key this morning. I feel as if I could
get over a stile just at hand and join the lambs in
their gambols." (!)

For nearly a year this truly happy and united
pair traveled from town to town together, one in
heart, in work, in all their hopes and joys. Many
converts were gathered in, and the constant testimony
of husband and wife was to ever-increasing love for
and delight in each other.

A visit to Halifax in March, 1856, was prolonged
by the arrival of "a plump, round-faced, dark-complexioned,
black-pated" little person, since known to
the world as William Bramwell Booth, Chief of the
Staff of the Salvation Army.

Concerning her first-born son, Mrs. Booth writes:—
"I held him up to God as soon as I had strength to
do so, and I remember specially desiring that he
should be an advocate of holiness. … At an early
age he manifested signs of intelligence and ability.
He resembled me especially in one particular, that
was in taking upon himself responsibility. He was
very conscientious too. … I cannot remember his
ever telling me a falsehood. … His energy as a child
was something marvellous."

Shortly after this event, Mr. Booth, at the wish of
the Conference, was induced for a while to relinquish
evangelistic work, and settle down in a circuit.
Brighouse in Yorkshire was the appointed scene of
his labours, and here the family remained about a
year. It was at Brighouse that their second son,
Ballington, was born. This was almost the only
pleasant event of that period, as Mr. Booth felt that
he had been unfairly dealt with by the Conference,
and that his special talent was being stifled. And
we need not say that his wife fully shared all his
views.

In May, 1858, William Booth received the rite of
ordination, and the consequent privilege of what is
termed "full connexion;" and although still hoping
and longing to return to the more congenial evangelistic
sphere, he consented to another year's circuit
work, this time at Gateshead.

Here the enthusiastic pair found themselves in
happier conditions. The very first Sunday night
they were there "six persons professed salvation, and
the occasion was made the more interesting by what
was then an unheard of novelty, the minister's wife
leading off in prayer at the conclusion of the sermon,"
which appears to have been Mrs. Booth's first appearance
in anything like a ministerial capacity in public.

Before long, the new pastor was drawing crowded
congregations, and the chapel had gained the sobriquet
of the "Converting Shop." It was here that he
first began to gain influence over the masses.

At Gateshead, in September, 1858, the Booths' first
little daughter, Catherine, was born. She is now Mrs.
Booth-Clibborn, otherwise the "Maréchale."

Some very successful "revival" work was done at
Gateshead, the methods of Mr. Booth as time went on
inclining more and more to the since well-known
"Salvation" type, "all-day prayer meetings," open air
processions, etc., being inaugurated. It was here also
that Mrs. Booth first gained courage to visit the poor
in their own homes, and urge them to attend the
mission services, and she was especially blessed in her
endeavours to reclaim drunkards. When the stipulated
twelve months at Gateshead had expired,
Mr. Booth was again persuaded to stay on as a
circuit minister instead of returning to his loved
work of itinerant evangelist.

In December, 1859, Mrs. Booth's attention was
drawn to a pamphlet written by a Mr. Rees, attacking
on Scriptural grounds the right of women to preach.
The exciting cause of this publication being the visit
of an American evangelist and his wife, Dr. and
Mrs. Palmer, the latter of whom took the more
prominent part in the meetings. Mrs. Booth was
highly indignant at this opposition, and was moved
to write a powerful and convincing pamphlet in reply.

This was the commencement of the life-long warfare
which she subsequently waged against the conventionality
that would forbid women the opportunity
of teaching in the church.

A good deal of interesting correspondence with
various people was evoked by the publication of
Mrs. Booth's protest, but it was not until after the
birth of her fourth child, Emma Moss Booth (Mrs.
Booth-Tucker) that she was able to champion in her
own person and by her example, the right of women
to speak as the Spirit gives them utterance.

head.hi:
CHAPTER IV.
THE MOTHER OF THE SALVATION ARMY.

div2.p:
It was in the spring of 1860 that Mrs. Booth made
her first appearance in her husband's pulpit.

Although she had for months been exercised in
mind on the subject, her action at last, after much
inward conflict and reluctance, was unpremeditated.

At the conclusion of one of Mr. Booth's services, she
suddenly rose, walked up the aisle, and told her
husband she wanted "to say a word."

Overcome by surprise and pleasure—for this was
what he had long been vainly trying to persuade her
to do—Mr. Booth could only say, "My dear wife
wishes to speak," and then sat down.

Then Mrs. Booth "just stood and told the people
how it had come about." She said she realised that
she had long, by her silence, been disobeying God,
and was resolved to do so no more.

The congregation were deeply affected; "many
dated a renewal in righteousness from that very
moment, and began a life of devotion and consecration
to God."

Yielding to her husband's entreaties, Mrs. Booth
consented, on the evening of the same day, to preach
a regular sermon.

Her text on this memorable occasion was, "Be filled
with the Spirit." The chapel was crowded to the
very window sills, and much blessing was received.

From this time forward Mrs. Booth's fame as a
preacher continued to spread far and wide. During
her husband's enforced absence for rest in September
of that same year, she undertook all his most important
services, and her letters of that period speak
enthusiastically of full congregations, blessed times,
and encouraging cases of conversion.

The following year the subject of personal holiness
was much borne in upon Mrs. Booth's mind, and
became a marked feature of her subsequent teachings.
In this connection one cannot but express the regret
which is called forth repeatedly during the writing of
this memoir, that the fervid intensity of Mrs. Booth's
religious convictions should not have escaped the
narrowness and intolerance which too often mars
piety of this type. Her sweeping condemnation of all
who did not think it necessary to advertise their
Christian profession by startling peculiarities in dress,
and her wholesale charges of coldness, hardness and
formality against those whose joy and peace in believing
were unaccompanied by moral earthquakes and
tornadoes, were certainly "flies in the ointment" of
an otherwise admirable character.

The Booths remained at Gateshead until 1861, when,
after much controversy with the Conference, into
which we have not space to enter here, Mr. Booth
finally tendered his resignation and gave himself up
to the revival work which was at once his delight and
his forte.

From that time forward, the conducting of missions
in various parts of the country became the life-work
of this devoted pair. Cornwall, Cardiff, Walsall,
Birmingham, and other places became in turn the
scene of their united efforts, and everywhere we find
the same record of "blessed seasons," "great liberty
of speech," weeping penitents and rejoicing converts.
Herbert Booth, the future musician of the Salvation
Army, was born at Penzance in 1862.

At Walsall Mrs. Booth experienced the joy of
receiving her own son, Bramwell, aged about eight, at
the juvenile penitent form. About a year previously
he had definitely refused the offer of salvation, so the
mother's thankfulness was now proportionately great.

In May, 1864, the sixth child, Marian, was born,
the first who seems in any way to have inherited that
delicate physical health against which Mrs. Booth's
dauntless spirit was doomed so continually to
struggle.

It was after her recovery from this illness that the
woman-evangelist first decided to conduct meetings
unassisted by her husband, and thus double their
power for good.

At Batley, Pudsey, and Wood house Carr she conducted
revival services with great success. At one of
these places in the course of six days, over one hundred
adults and two hundred children came forward as
penitents to the communion rail.

In 1865, Mr. and Mrs. Booth took up their abode
in London, and here, in a marquee in the Quaker
burial-ground at Whitechapel, the great Salvation
Army may be said to have had its birth.

Into this big tent were gathered, night after night,
the poorest and vilest of the outcasts of the great city,
and at meeting after meeting tears of penitence were
shed, and new lives begun. But while William Booth
felt his sympathies go out especially to those of the
most wretched classes, his wife's ministry seemed
peculiarly acceptable to those of superior social
position, and even when she spoke most plainly
respecting society sins, denouncing the selfishness of
fashion, the cruelty of stag-hunting, or the brutality
of war in scathing terms, the long line of carriages
waiting outside the hall in which her addresses were
delivered, testified that her frankness attracted rather
than repelled those whom she was desirous to influence.
As her biographer remarks, "it was a singular
coincidence that at the very time when Mr. Booth was
commencing his East End campaign, Mrs. Booth was
conducting her first West End services, so that the
very antipodes of London society were simultaneously
assailed." And Mrs. Booth's impassioned appeals to
the rich were often the means of obtaining money
wherewith to continue the evangelising work among
the poor. Surely no husband and wife were ever
more truly united, or exemplified more beautifully
the law of mutual complement than did William and
Catherine Booth!

Ultimately "the General," as we must now call
him, decided to abandon itinerant mission work, and
devote himself wholly to the East End poor. In this
determination he met with a staunch ally and generous
supporter in Mr. Samuel Morley, M.P., who once
described himself at a Salvation Army meeting as a
"sleeping partner" in the concern.

When the tent in the burial-ground was blown
down in a gale, a dancing saloon was secured, in
which the services could be held; and the East
London Mission, as for a time it was called, grew and
flourished.

On Christmas Day, 1865, a seventh child (being the
fourth daughter) was added to the Booth family, and
received the appropriate name of Evangeline.

Again and again was Mrs. Booth prostrated by
weakness and maladies of various forms, and as often,
in answer to fervent prayer, was she restored to comparative
health and the ability to continue her work.
But her whole life was a chronic martyrdom of bodily
suffering, such as only the strongest spirit, upborne
by a constant sense of Divine help, could have sustained.

On the 28th of April, 1867, was born the eighth and
last child, another girl, who was named Lucy Milward.
Like her sister, Marian, she has been of a delicate
constitution, and while others worked and fought, it
has been her lot to be among those who "also serve,"
though they may only "stand and wait."

Meanwhile, the older children were all following in
the steps of their father and mother, holding little
meetings among themselves and their young companions
at a very early age. Their letters to their
parents on various occasions of separation teem with
expressions of religious fervour, and record efforts
made for the spiritual enlightenment and moral
restoration of those with whom they were thrown
Their self-examination and contemplation also
resembled that of their mother in her youth, and their
fluctuations of religious feeling were carefully noted
down at an age when most children are absorbed in
their lessons and play. This complete reproduction,
in each and all, of the parental characteristics, was
probably the result of Mrs. Booth's carefulness in
Keeping them as much as possible from any association
with persons, either old or young, of a different
type, until her own views were stamped indelibly upon
their plastic souls.

Ever busy as Mrs. Booth always was with her important
mission of converting the lost, she never
allowed that to betray her into neglect of nearer
duties. Her children's welfare, both bodily and
spiritual, was her constant care. She prayed and
laboured that they might be true Christians and
earnestly devoted to the work of saving souls; the
remarkable manner in which this, her dearest wish,
has been fulfilled, is sufficient evidence that she
sought its furtherance in the best way.

Complete severance from what she regarded as
"the world," was ever a cardinal point in Mrs. Booth's
principles, and she naturally enforced it upon her
family, as it was afterwards made a leading feature
in the discipline of the Salvation Army. Even the
beautiful frocks, etc., which the children's grandmother
made for them with her own hands, were
stripped of all superfluous ornamentation before they
were permitted to be worn.

In December, 1869, Mrs. Booth experienced a heavy
sorrow in the death of Mrs. Mumford, after a period
of intense suffering. The devoted daughter had persuaded
her mother some months earlier, when it was
known that the disease which had attacked the latter
must be fatal, to come up to London and live near her,
so the two had the mutual comfort of being together
when the end came, and Mrs. Mumford's happy and
glorious departure was the greatest possible solace
to Mrs. Booth.

In 1870, the People's Market in Whitechapel Road
was purchased, and here "All-Nights of Prayer" were
first conducted by Mrs. Booth; and here also the
East London Mission tried its earliest experiment in
the sale of cheap food to the poor.

In 1872, the General broke down under the strain
of his prolonged exertions, and was completely laid
aside for six months. During his illness and enforced
absence, Mrs. Booth managed the affairs of
the Mission with ability and success. On the return
of her husband she arranged what proved to be one
of her most successful campaigns she ever undertook
—that of Portsmouth, in 1873.

She engaged a music hall in the lowest part of
the town and gathered immense crowds of soldiers
and sailors, their companions, and "the worst and
most Gospel-needy classes in the town." The services
lasted seventeen weeks, and the names of six hundred
converts were taken. The morning meetings on this
memorable occasion were devoted to professing
Christians, and for twelve consecutive Sundays
Mrs. Booth based her addresses upon the one text,
"Go work to-day in My vineyard!" She spoke for
about an hour each time, and so far from exhausting
her subject, could only promise her hearers that she
would resume it on the following Sunday, but
MRS. BOOTH AT THE MANCHESTER FREE TRADE HALL.
whether to conclude or not was more than she
could tell!

In 1874, Mrs. Booth became deeply interested in
the American Whisky War, and the result was the
inauguration by the Mission of a Drunkards' Rescue
Brigade, which from the first was "signally blessed
in reaching and reclaiming many of the most forlorn
and degraded of this class."

In 1875, we find Mrs. Booth suffering acutely from
her second attack of angina pectoris. For several
weeks she was confined to her room, her symptoms
at times being most agonising and alarming. Hydropathy
was, however, on this occasion, resorted to,
and with such happy effects that, after a period of
rest, she became able to continue her beloved work
once more.

The following years were especially marked by
the appearance of several of the young Booths in
public as assistants in their parents' work. As
early as 1870, indeed, Bramwell,then a lad of only
fourteen, had commenced to address adult congregations,
both indoors and in the open air. Shortly
after, Catherine followed her brother's example, and
she, too, was scarcely more than a child when she
first spoke to an audience in the street. Emma
commenced in 1877, and the others, one by one,
joined the ranks of preachers in the Mission at an
astonishingly tender age.

It was not until the Christmas of this year (1877),
that the Mission was called by its afterwards world-famed
name of "The Salvation Army." This was
Mr. Booth's own idea, and it was used first on his
annual printed appeal for help.

The military notion once started, it was found so
singularly suitable to the work in many ways, that
"Captains," "Colonels," and "Corps," soon followed.
A flag was designed, of which the blue border
symbolised holiness, the scarlet ground typified salvation
by the blood of Christ, and the yellow star in
the centre betokened the baptism of the Holy Ghost.
Similarly, the motto of the Army, "Blood and Fire,"
represents salvation and the fire of the Spirit. It
was an easy and natural thing that the title of
"General Superintendent of the Mission," which
Mr. Booth had long borne, should be shortened into
simply "The General," and with, finally, a uniform
designed by Mrs. Booth, in accordance with her
ambition to look, as well as be, totally unlike "the
world," the army scheme was complete.

After this, the annals of the services teem with experiences
of "bombardments" accomplished, "strongholds"
taken, and "battles" won. The poorest, the
most ignorant, and the most degraded were reached
and touched as had never been known before, and
such characters as "Happy Eliza," "The Converted
Sweep," and the "Hallelujah Giant," were convincing
evidences of the reality of the victories
gained.

In 1880 the War Cry was launched, and although
by this and other literary work the General and his
wife might have attained a position of affluence, they
chose rather to devote the proceeds of the successful
enterprise to the extension of their work.

Limitations of space compel us to pass over much
that is deeply interesting in the record of succeeding
years. Confining ourselves, of necessity, to a sketch
of the life of Catherine Booth only, we must reluctantly
omit all reference to the many thrilling episodes
in the careers and triumphs of her children, and pass
over in silence the names of many noteworthy and
influential friends of the Army.

In 1882, the work was carried into India, Sweden
and Canada, as in the previous year Miss Booth and
her band of soldiers had invaded France on their campaign
of peace.

The year 1882 was also marked by the marriage of
Mrs. Booth's eldest son, Bramwell, to a young lady
enthusiastically devoted to the work.

In 1885, the Booths were participators with Mrs.
Josephine Butler, Mr. Stead, and others, in the famous
Purity Agitation, and were instrumental in bringing
about the passing of the much-needed Criminal Law
Amendment Act. They also shared in the penalties
which followed upon Mr. Stead's bold action in the
matter, but emerged safe and triumphant from
all their trials, and with increased desires to
guard and befriend the unprotected young girls
of London.

It was in this year also that All the World was
first published, a magazine which sought to address
those to whom the rough-and-ready style of the
War Cry was hardly acceptable.

Mrs. Booth, once more prostrated by illness, now
utilised her enforced leisure in writing letters to the
latter paper on different subjects suggested by the
difficulties of private correspondents, who sought her
counsel from all parts of the world. The answer to a
father who was in despair concerning the conduct of
his grown-up sons, that to a young lady, uneasy about
her intended marriage to an unconverted lover, and
another, embodying Mrs. Booth's views on the subject
of spiritualism, may be mentioned as indicating the
variety and scope of the topics with which she so ably
and sensibly dealt. Our only regret is that we cannot
reproduce some of these wise essays in full.

But we must pass on to the closing activities of this
remarkable life.

During the latter half of 1886 and the whole of
1887, Mrs. Booth not only held crowded meetings in
Exeter Hall, and most of the large Salvation Army
halls in London, but visited nearly twenty provincial
towns in all parts of England. Her denunciations of
evil grew stronger and more severe as she realised
with greater intensity the need of plain speaking
with regard to sin. Nevertheless, her popularity
did not undergo the slightest diminution, and at this
period it may be said that as a preacher she was in
the zenith of her success.

Between the years 1886 and 1890, four more of
Mrs. Booth's children were happily and suitably
wedded, the chosen partner in each case being
one whose whole heart was in the work of the
Army.

In 1886, Commander Ballington Booth was married
to Miss Maud Charlesworth; in 1887 the Maréchale
gave her hand to Commissioner Booth-Clibborn; in
1888 Miss Emma Booth became Mrs. Booth-Tucker,
and the last of the four was Commandant
Herbert Booth, who was united to Miss Coraline
Schoch.

It is a sad transition from the wedding-feast to the
chamber of death! But even at the time that this
last wedding took place, Mrs. Booth's family realised
with anguish that her days on earth were numbered,
and she was already too ill to be present at the
ceremony.

On the 21st of June, 1888, the great woman-evangelist
gave her last public address, and the scene of
this farewell utterance was the City Temple.

On this occasion, all forgetful of her weakness in
her enthusiasm for the souls of those who listened,
Mrs. Booth spoke for upwards of an hour, but so exhausted
was she at the close that it was some considerable
time before she could be removed from the
pulpit.

In the autumn of this year she stayed for a while
at "Oceanville," Clacton-on-Sea—a house previously
selected by her as a home of rest for the officers of
the Army. But she received no permanent benefit
from the visit. She liked the quiet of the place so
much, however, that she returned in August, 1889,
and remained there until her death.

After Mrs. Booth was incapacitated from work in
public, and even, by the effect of the disease upon her
right arm, unable any longer to write, she continued
to dictate letters and advise with those who sought
her help.

Her last message to the myriads who loved and
honoured her, looking upon her as their spiritual
mother, was unrolled before the eyes of the 20,000
persons who were gathered in the nave of the Crystal
Palace at the anniversary celebration in 1890. It had
been printed upon a wide strip of calico, in letters so
large that it could be deciphered in all parts of the
building, and ran as follows:—

"My dear Children and Friends,—My place is
empty, but my heart is with you. You are my joy and
my crown. Your battles, sufferings and victories have
been the chief interests of my life these twenty-five
years. They are so still. Go forward. Live holy
lives. Be true to the Army. God is your strength.
Love and seek the lost; bring them to the blood.
OCEANVILLE, CLACTON-ON-SEA.
Make the people good; inspire them with the Spirit
of Jesus Christ. Love one another; help your
comrades in dark hours. I am dying under the Army
flag; it is yours to live and fight under. God is my
salvation and refuge in the storm. I send you my
love and blessing.—Catherine Booth."

"The effect", we are told, "was electrical. The
whole congregation was bathed in tears, and from
thousands of hearts there went up fresh vows of consecration
recorded in Heaven, and since fulfilled on
earth."

On the 4th of October 1890, after having bidden
most touching farewells to all her children and grandchildren,
and many of the more prominent members
INTERIOR OF MRS. BOOTH'S SITTING-ROOM, OCEANVILLE.
(The Vacant Chair.)
of the Salvation Army, the grand, indomitable spirit
of Catherine Booth was at length released from its
tenement of pain. Her last audible words were,
"I see!"

One might fill pages with graphic descriptions of
the "lying-in-state" at the Congress Hall, Clapton,
when the body in a coffin with a glass panel was
viewed by upwards of 40,000 persons, and of the
funeral at Olympia, attended by 36,000, while
thousands more were turned away for want of room.
But our task is done; and we cannot better close
this inadequate memoir than with two verses
which aptly describe the feelings of those left
behind:—
"'Promoted to glory'! From leading our legions,
Not parted for ever, but gone on before;
'Promoted,' exalted to Paradise regions,
'Promoted,' not perished, 'than conqueror more.'
'Promoted to glory!' Blest Mother, we'll follow!
By blood and by fire our foes we'll defeat.
We'll 'love one another,' scorn earth-joys so hollow,
And march on until 'in the morning' we meet."
THE END.
